The patient is given a Â«magic pillÂ» that makes the tumor glow under blue light. The surgeon studies a 3D map of the brain to accurately plan the incision.
ðŸ“Œ Interesting point: sometimes the operation is done Â«on awakeningÂ» so as not to affect the speech zones!

description.professional:
Linear/arc-shaped skin incision preserving the feeding vessels. Burr hole with a craniotome (5 mm burr). Osteoplastic craniotomy with the formation of a bone flap (size 2 cm larger than the tumor borders). Hemostasis of the bone edges with wax.
Instruments:
- Pneumatic burr (Anspach or Midas Rex)
- Bone wax
- Dural hooks
Technique:
1. Sawing the bone while preserving the periosteum.
2. Control of the position of the sinuses (at parasagittal tumors).
Logistics:
- The bone flap is stored in antibiotic-saline solution.
Nuance: In case of bone invasion â€” hyperostosis resection.
description.normal:
A Â«windowÂ» is cut out in the skull to get to the tumor. The bone is preserved â€” it will be put back.
ðŸ“Œ Interesting point: the tumor can grow into the bone, then part of it is also removed.

steps.name: Opening the dura mater and visualizing the tumor

description.professional:
Incision of the dura mater with a #11 scalpel in the avascular zone. Fixation of the edges with sutures (4-0 silk). Turning on blue light (405 nm) to activate 5-ALA fluorescence (the tumor glows pink). Marking the boundaries using neuronavigation data.
Instruments:
- Microscope with a fluorescence module (Zeiss Pentero 900)
- Ultrasonic aspirator (CUSA EXcel)
- Bipolar coagulation (Malis, 15 W)
Technique:
1. Fluorescence confirms the tumor area (100% specificity).
2. Ultrasound navigation to determine the depth.
Logistics:
- Collection of material for urgent histology.
Note: If there is no luminescence, neuronavigation control is used.
description.normal:
Under blue light, the tumor turns pink - like a neon sign. This helps the surgeon avoid damaging the healthy brain.
ðŸ“Œ Interesting point: 5-ALA makes the tumor visible only under special light!

description.professional:
Tumor enucleation with an ultrasonic aspirator (CUSA) while preserving the pial vessels. Gradual coagulation of tumor tissue with a bipolar. Control of boundaries by fluorescence and neuronavigation. When close to functional zones â€” corticography and direct electrical stimulation.
Instruments:
- CUSA (frequency 28 kHz, aspiration 60%)
- Rhoton microforceps No. 4
- Neuromonitoring (NIM Eclipse)
Technique:
1. Resection from the center to the periphery.
2. In case of invasion into the ventricle â€” stop to prevent dissemination.
3. Motor evoked potential monitoring.
Logistics:
- Tumor tissue is sent for histology and molecular analysis (MGMT, IDH1).
Nuance: If the motor cortex is affected, subtotal resection is performed while preserving the functional island.
description.normal:
The tumor is Â«sucked outÂ» with a special ultrasound device that breaks it into small pieces. The vessels are cauterized.
ðŸ“Œ An interesting point: if the tumor is near the area responsible for movement, the surgeon can leave a thin layer to avoid paralysis.

description.professional:
Intraoperative MRI (if available) to assess residual tumor. Repeated fluorescence under blue light. Hemostasis of the tumor bed with a hemostatic sponge (Surgicel). Installation of a capsule with carmustine (Gliadel) upon agreement with the oncologist.
Instruments:
- Intraoperative MRI (BrainSuite)
- Hemostatic sponges (Floseal, Surgicel)
- Implantable capsule with a chemotherapy drug
Technique:
1. MRI control 30 minutes after resection.
2. Additional resection in case of residual tumor.
Logistics:
- Recording of data for postoperative radiation therapy.
Nuance: With localization in functional zones, residual tumor volume is acceptable (STR, subtotal resection).
description.name:
After removal, an MRI is done right in the operating room to check if there is any tumor left. Sometimes a Â«tabletÂ» with a chemotherapy drug is placed in the tumor bed.
ðŸ“Œ Interesting point: modern technologies allow scanning the brain during surgery!

description.professional:
Sealed suturing of the dura mater (Prolene 4-0). Return of the bone flap with fixation with titanium plates. Drainage of the epidural space (Redon drainage 10 Fr). Layered suturing of the wound.
Instruments:
- Titanium plates and screws (1.5 mm)
- Drainage with active aspiration
- Vicryl suture material 2-0
Postoperative protocol:
1. CT scan after 2 hours to exclude hematoma.
2. Dexamethasone 4 mg Ã—4 times a day (edema prevention).
3. Start of radiation therapy in 2-4 weeks.
Complications:
- Neurological deficit (15-20%).
- Infection (3-5%).
- Relapse (100% within 2 years without adjuvant therapy).
description.normal:
The bone is put back in place, the wound is sutured. Radiation and chemotherapy begin in a couple of weeks.
ðŸ“Œ Hard fact: glioblastoma always comes back, but surgery prolongs life for years.

modes.professional: Radical removal of the epileptogenic zone (temporal/frontal lobectomy, selective amygdalohippocampectomy) or disconnection of pathological neural networks (callosotomy). Stages: intraoperative EEG, corticography, neuronavigation, functional mapping. Control of the preservation of functional zones (speech, motor) is critical.
modes.normal: Surgery, which stops epileptic seizures. The surgeon removes or Â«disablesÂ» the area of the brain where the seizures originate. Most often, the temporal lobes are operated on.

description.professional:
Video-EEG monitoring (3-7 days), high-resolution MRI (3T), PET, functional MRI (speech/motor areas). Implantation of subdural grids or depth electrodes if the data do not match. Wada test to assess hemisphere dominance for speech.
Instruments:
- Stereotactic system (FrameLink, BrainLab)
- Depth electrodes (DIXI Medical)
- Intraoperative neurophysiological monitoring (Natus)
Technique:
1. Accurate definition of the epileptogenic zone based on ictal/interictal EEG data.
2. Tractorography to assess proximity to conduction pathways.
Logistics:
- Comparison of EEG, MRI, and clinical semiotics of seizures.
Nuance: In case of bilateral hippocampal damage â€” decision on sequential surgeries.
description.usual:
Before the surgery, the patient lives with electrodes on the head for a week to Â«catchÂ» the seizure on the EEG. They do an MRI and speech tests.
ðŸ“Œ Interesting point: sometimes electrodes are temporarily implanted in the brain to accurately determine the lesion.

description.professional:
Positioning: on the side (with temporal approach) or on the back (frontal lobe). Fixation of the head in Mayfield. Arcuate skin incision (temporal approach: from the zygomatic arch to the parietal tubercle). Craniotomy 4x4 cm with preservation of the bone flap. Opening of the dura mater in the avascular zone.
Instruments:
- Pneumatic burr (Midas Rex with a 5 mm burr)
- Double-pronged soft tissue hooks
- Microscope (Zeiss OPMI Pentero)
Technique:
1. For temporal lobectomy â€” access through the middle temporal gyrus.
2. For frontal resection â€” bypass Broca's area.
Logistics:
- The bone flap is stored in warm saline with an antibiotic.
Note: For callosotomy â€” parasagittal approach with preservation of the paracentral lobules.
description.normal:
The skull is opened above the problem area. In temporal lobe epilepsy, the incision goes from the temple to the crown.
ðŸ“Œ Interesting point: the bone is always returned to its place - it takes root as if it were native.

description.professional:
Application of electrodes to the cortex (subdural strips/grid). Recording of interictal activity. Direct electrical stimulation (1-5 mA) for mapping speech/motor zones. Marking of functionally significant areas with sterile markers.
Instruments:
- Cortical electrodes (Ad-Tech Medical)
- Ojemann stimulator (Natus)
- Neuronavigation with fMRI data integration
Technique:
1. Stimulation with a step of 5 mm (frequency 50 Hz, duration 1 ms).
2. Motor response control (face, arm, leg).
Logistics:
- Mapping of the Broca/Wernicke area in the dominant hemisphere.
Note: Plasticity is possible in children under 5 years old - resection in the dominant hemisphere with caution.
description.normal:
The brain is Â«listenedÂ» to with electrodes and checked which areas are responsible for speech and movement.
ðŸ“Œ An interesting point: during stimulation, the patient can start talking or moving their hand - this helps the surgeon not to touch important areas.

description.professional:
**Temporal lobectomy**: removal of the anterior 3-4 cm of the temporal lobe (non-dominant hemisphere) or 2-3 cm (dominant). **Amygdalohippocampectomy**: transcortical approach through the middle temporal gyrus to the hippocampus. **Frontal resection**: neuronavigation-guided removal of cortical dysplasia.
Instruments:
- Ultrasonic aspirator (CUSA EXcel, 30% power)
- Bipolar forceps (Malis, 10 W)
- Rhoton microforceps #3
Technique:
1. Gradual aspiration of the cortex while preserving white matter.
2. In hippocampectomy â€” control of pial vessels (risk of brainstem damage).
Logistics:
- Samples are sent for histology (FCD I-III according to Blumcke).
Nuance: In mesial temporal sclerosis â€” mandatory hippocampal resection.
description.normal:
The surgeon removes the area of the brain where seizures originate. In temporal epilepsy, this is the tip of the temporal lobe and the hippocampus (it looks like a seahorse).
ðŸ“Œ Hard fact: the hippocampus is Â«memoryÂ», but after its removal the patient forgets only the last 1-2 years.

description.professional:
Dissection of the corpus callosum (anterior 2/3 in tonic-clonic seizures or 100% in Lennox-Gastaut syndrome). Access through the interhemispheric fissure. Step-by-step coagulation and incision with microscissors. Control of the safety of the pericallosal arteries.
Instruments:
- Microscope with Ã—20-40 magnification
- Yasargil microscissors
- Bipolar coagulation (15 W)
Technique:
1. Separation of the hemispheres with a blunt retractor.
2. Gradual dissection of the corpus callosum fibers.
Logistics:
- Intraoperative ultrasound to control the depth.
Nuance: In case of Lennox-Gastaut syndrome â€” additional subpial resection.
description.normal:
The Â«bridgeÂ» between the hemispheres of the brain is cut so that the seizures do not spread.
ðŸ“Œ Interesting point: after this operation, the patient can write with his left hand without realizing it (Â«alien handÂ» syndrome).

description.professional:
Repeat intraoperative EEG to assess epileptiform activity. Hermetic suturing of the dura mater (Prolene 4-0). Fixation of the bone flap with titanium plates. Subdural space drainage (Redon 10 Fr drainage).
Instruments:
- Titanium plates (1.0 mm)
- Drainage with active aspiration
- Vicryl 2-0 suture material
Postoperative protocol:
1. Video-EEG monitoring 24-48 hours.
2. MRI after 72 hours to assess radicality.
3. Gradual withdrawal of antiepileptic drugs (after 6-12 months).
Complications:
- Hemianopsia (with resection of the occipital lobe).
- Transient aphasia (10-15%).
- Hydrocephalus (rare).
description.normal:
The wound is sutured, the patient is transferred to the ward. The attacks may disappear immediately or after several months.
ðŸ“Œ Good news: 70% of patients live without attacks after surgery!

modes.professional: Microsurgical removal of a herniated disc with decompression of the spinal nerve root. Stages: paramedian approach, hemilaminectomy, foraminotomy, removal of a herniated disc under the control of an operating microscope. Control of the integrity of the dural sac and the nerve root is critical.
modes.normal: An operation that removes the Â«pinchingÂ» of a nerve due to a herniated disc in the lumbar region. The surgeon removes the hernia through a small incision, and the leg pain goes away almost immediately.

description.professional:
The patient is positioned on his stomach with a bend in the lumbar region (the Â«knees-chestÂ» position). Skin marking based on intraoperative fluoroscopy data: projection of the affected segment (usually L4-L5 or L5-S1). Treatment of the surgical field. Infiltration anesthesia (1% lidocaine with adrenaline).
Instruments:
- X-ray C-arm
- 22G spinal needles
- Surgical marker
Technique:
1. Determining the level using an X-ray (control by the iliac crest).
2. Marking a 3-4 cm long incision 1.5 cm from the midline.
Logistics:
- Checking the level of anesthesia before the incision.
Nuance: In case of obesity (BMI> 35) â€” increasing the incision length to 5 cm.
description.normal:
The patient is placed on his stomach, with a pillow under the lower back. The sore spot is marked with an X-ray and the incision line is drawn.
ðŸ“Œ Interesting point: the incision is so small that the scar is almost invisible!

description.professional:
Incision of the skin, subcutaneous tissue and lumbosacral fascia. Blunt separation of the muscles (multifidus and longissimus) using dilators. Installation of a tubular retractor (e.g. METRx). Hemilaminectomy with Kerrison nippers (size 2-3 mm) with exposure of the yellow ligament.
Instruments:
- Tubular retractor (diameter 18-20 mm)
- Kerrison nippers (1-3 mm)
- Electrocoagulator (Valleylab, 20 W)
Technique:
1. Bipolar coagulation of epidural veins.
2. Resection of the lower edge of the overlying vertebral arch.
Logistics:
- Bone fragments are disposed of as biological waste.
Nuance: In case of facet joint hypertrophy â€” partial facetectomy.
description.normal:
Through the incision, the surgeon moves the muscles apart like curtains and gets to the vertebra. Using special Â«nippersÂ» he removes part of the bone to see the nerve.
ðŸ“Œ Interesting point: the muscles are not cut - they are simply moved aside, so the recovery is fast.

description.professional:
Excision of the yellow ligament (ligamentotomy). Identification of the dural sac and root. Mobilization of the root medially (in case of medial hernia) or laterally (in case of foraminal hernia). Discectomy with a microcoagulator and pulp forceps. Hemostasis control with a bipolar.
Instruments:
- Microsurgical forceps (Pituitary rongeurs)
- Penfield dissector No. 4
- Binocular microscope (magnification Ã—10-16)
Technique:
1. Incision of the fibrous ring with a scalpel No. 11.
2. Removal of hernial material and degenerative nucleus pulposus.
3. Revision of the spinal canal for sequesters.
Logistics:
- The removed material is sent for histology.
Nuance: In the case of a massive adhesive process, a dural protector is used.
description.normal:
The surgeon finds the nerve and carefully moves it to the side. The hernia is pulled out with small forceps, like a splinter.
ðŸ“Œ Interesting point: the hernia looks like on a piece of chewing gum â€” soft and sticky.

description.professional:
Checking the freedom of the root with passive movements. Foraminotomy for stenosis of the intervertebral foramen (with Kerrison pliers 1 mm). Washing the wound with sterile saline. Installation of a hemostatic sponge (Surgicel). Intraoperative test for segment stability (if instability is suspected â€” transpedicular fixation).
Instruments:
- Nerve hook
- Irrigator with warm saline
- Hemostatic sponge (Gelfoam)
Technique:
1. Palpation of the root with a hook â€” it should move freely.
2. Checking for the absence of disc fragments in the epidural space.
Logistics:
- Fixation of the retractor by an assistant during revision.
Nuance: In case of recurrent hernias â€” use of adgeolysis (hyaluronidase).
description.normal:
The surgeon checks that the nerve lies freely in its Â«bedÂ». If necessary, he widens the opening through which the nerve exits the spine.
ðŸ“Œ An interesting point: after releasing the nerve, the patient immediately feels that the pain goes away.

description.professional:
Removal of the retractor. Layer-by-layer suturing of the wound: fascia (Vicryl 2-0), subcutaneous tissue (Vicryl 3-0), skin (monofilament 4-0). Application of a sterile dressing. Extubation and transfer to the ward.
Instruments:
- Mathieu needle holder
- Suture material (absorbable/non-absorbable)
- Sterile wipes
Postoperative protocol:
1. Activation after 2-3 hours.
2. Pain relief (paracetamol + NSAIDs).
3. Discharge on the 2-3 day.
Complications:
- Liquorrhea (1-2%).
- Hernia recurrence (5-10%).
- Root injury (0.5%).
description.normal:
The muscles are returned to their place, the incision is sutured. After a couple of hours, the patient can already get up.
ðŸ“Œ Good news: 90% of patients forget about leg pain immediately after surgery!

modes.professional: Surgical decompression of the spinal canal by removing the vertebral arch (lamina) and spinous process. Indications: spinal stenosis, spinal cord compression, tumors. Stages: access, resection of bone structures, decompression of the dural sac, stabilization (if necessary).
modes.normal: Surgery that widens the Â«narrowÂ» spinal canal to release the compressed spinal cord and nerves. After this, the patient can walk again without pain.

description.professional:
The patient is positioned on his stomach with a lumbar arch (knees-chest position). Skin markings according to fluoroscopy data: projection of the affected segments (usually L3-L5). A midline skin incision 8-10 cm long. Layer-by-layer dissection of the subcutaneous tissue and lumbosacral fascia.
Instruments:
- Scalpel No. 20
- Electrocoagulator (Valleylab, 30 W)
- Retractors (e.g., Taylor or Williams)
Technique:
1. Midline incision from the spinous process of the overlying to the underlying vertebra.
2. Detachment of paravertebral muscles from spinous processes and arches subperiosteally.
Logistics:
- Bleeding vessels are coagulated with bipolar.
Nuance: During cervical laminectomy - fixation of the head in Mayfield with slight flexion.
description.normal:
The patient is placed on his stomach, placing a cushion under the lower back. The surgeon makes an incision along the spine and carefully moves the muscles to the sides.
ðŸ“Œ Interesting point: the muscles are not cut - they are Â«peeled offÂ» from the bone, like the peel of an orange.

description.professional:
Removal of spinous processes with Liston nippers. Resection of the lamina with a high-speed burr (e.g. Midas Rex with a 4 mm burr) or Kerrison rongeurs (size 2-3 mm). Control of the integrity of the dural sac. Facetectomy if necessary.
Instruments:
- Liston rongeurs
- Pneumatic rongeur (Midas Rex)
- Kerrison rongeurs (2-3 mm)
Technique:
1. Initial resection at the base of the spinous process.
2. Gradual removal of the lamina from the caudal to the cranial direction.
3. Control of the resection depth to avoid damaging the dural sac.
Logistics:
- Bone fragments are preserved for possible plastic surgery.
Nuance: In case of hypertrophy of the facet joints - partial resection of the medial sections.
description.normal:
The surgeon removes the bone Â«wingsÂ» of the vertebrae (spinous processes and arches) to make room for the spinal cord.
ðŸ“Œ Interesting point: the bone is sometimes preserved - it can be used for plastic surgery.

steps.name: Decompression of the dural sac and roots

description.professional:
Excision of the yellow ligament (ligamentotomy). Microsurgical decompression roots: dissection of adhesions, removal of osteophytes. Revision of the spinal canal for disc herniation or tumors. Washing the wound with warm saline.
Instruments:
- Microforceps (Pituitary rongeurs)
- Penfield dissector No. 4
- Binocular loupe (Ã—3.5)
Technique:
1. Careful separation of the yellow ligament from the dural sac.
2. Blunt mobilization of the roots.
3. Removal of compressive factors (osteophytes, hernias).
Logistics:
- Hemostasis of epidural veins with bipolar (15 W).
Nuance: In case of pronounced adhesions â€” use of dural protector.
description.normal:
The surgeon releases the spinal cord and nerves, removing everything that compresses them: ligaments, bone spurs (osteophytes), hernias.
ðŸ“Œ Important: nerves are as delicate as live wires â€” they are easy to damage!

description.professional:
In case of segment instability or multiple resections â€” transpedicular fixation (CD Horizon system or similar). Installation of titanium screws in the vertebral pedicles and their connection with rods. Decortication of the remaining bone structures to stimulate fusion.
Instruments:
- Transpedicular screws (diameter 5.5-6.5 mm)
- Rods (diameter 5.5 mm)
- X-ray C-arm to control the position of the screws
Technique:
1. Screw insertion point: junction of superior articular process and transverse process.
2. Insertion angle: 10-15Â° medially in the lumbar region.
3. Depth control by X-ray.
Logistics:
- Checking the position of the screws with intraoperative fluoroscopy.
Nuance: In case of osteoporosis, use cement screws.
description.normal:
If a lot of bone is removed, the spine is strengthened with titanium screws and rods.
ðŸ“Œ Interesting point: the screws are screwed into the Â«pediclesÂ» of the vertebrae - these are the strongest places.

description.professional:
Hemostasis (Surgicel, bone wax). Installation of drainage (Redon 10 Fr). Layered suturing of the wound: fascia (Vicryl 2-0), subcutaneous tissue (Vicryl 3-0), skin (monofilament 4-0). Application of a sterile dressing.
Instruments:
- Drainage with active aspiration
- Mathieu needle holder
- Suture material
Postoperative protocol:
1. Activation after 6-12 hours.
2. Pain relief (NSAIDs + weak opioids).
3. Wearing a corset for 4-6 weeks (with fixation).
Complications:
- Cerebrospinal fluid leakage (1-3%).
- Segment instability (5-10%).
- Infection (1-2%).
description.normal:
The wound is sutured, leaving drainage for 1-2 days. The patient can get up after a few hours.
ðŸ“Œ Good news: 80% of patients report a decrease in leg pain immediately after surgery!

modes.professional: Surgical stabilization of the spinal segment with the creation of a bone block. Methods: PLIF (posterior), TLIF (transforaminal), ALIF (anterior). Stages: discectomy, installation of a cage with a bone graft, transpedicular fixation. The angle of cage installation and the compression force are critical.
modes.normal: An operation that Â«fuse[s]Â» diseased vertebrae into a single block using metal structures and a bone graft. After this, the spine stops Â«walkingÂ» and hurting.

description.professional:
**Posterior approach (TLIF/PLIF)**: Midline incision 8-12 cm. Subperiosteal detachment of the paravertebral muscles to the facet joints. Resection of the spinous process and vertebral arch (if necessary). **Anterior approach (ALIF)**: Incision along the left rectus abdominis muscle. Retroperitoneal approach to the spine with vascular mobilization.
Instruments:
- Electrocoagulator (Force Triad, 30 W)
- Bone raspators (Cobb, Hohmann)
- Retractor (e.g. Williams for posterior approach)
Technique:
1. For TLIF â€” partial facetectomy to access the disc.
2. For ALIF â€” identification of the aortic bifurcation and iliac vessels.
Logistics:
- Marking the surgical level with a C-arm X-ray.
Note: For ALIF in men â€” risk of retrograde ejaculation (damage to the superior hypogastric plexus).
description.normal:
The surgeon makes an incision on the back (less often on the abdomen) and carefully moves the muscles aside to reach the vertebrae.
ðŸ“Œ Interesting point: with anterior access, the intestine is temporarily moved aside - it then returns to its place!

description.professional:
Full discectomy with pulp forceps. Resection of the endplates with a burr (for example, Midas Rex with a ball attachment) to the bleeding bone (puncture bleeding). Washing the disc space with antibiotic-saline. Measuring the depth and height of the bed.
Instruments:
- Disc forceps (Pituitary rongeurs)
- Burr with a 5 mm ball attachment
- Calibration probes (in 1 mm increments)
Technique:
1. Removal of the disc up to the fibrous ring along the perimeter.
2. Decortication of the endplates without destroying the cortical layer.
3. Formation of grooves for the cage (with TLIF).
Logistics:
- The removed disc is sent for histology.
Nuance: In osteoporosis - minimal resection of the endplates.
description.normal:
The surgeon removes the damaged disc between the vertebrae and clears the space down to the Â«bleedingÂ» bone - this is necessary for better fusion.
ðŸ“Œ Important: the space is measured like a tailor - so that the cage (implant) fits perfectly.

steps.name: Installation of a cage and bone graft

description.professional:
Implantation of a cage (PEEK, titanium or ceramics) with bone chips (autograft from the iliac crest or allograft). In TLIF - installation of the cage at an angle of 45Â° through the foraminal window. Compression of the cage during fixation with rods.
Instruments:
- Cage (dimensions 8-14 mm high, 22-30 mm long)
- Implant holder
- Mallet for final seating
Technique:
1. Filling the cage with bone chips (mixed with BMP-2 if necessary).
2. Control of the cage position with an X-ray (should not protrude beyond the disc).
3. With TLIF â€” cage rotation in the frontal plane to restore lordosis.
Logistics:
- The remaining chips are placed in the side pockets.
Nuance: With ALIF â€” use of cages with a large lordosis angle (10-15Â°).
description.normal:
A Â«cageÂ» with bone chips is placed in the cleared space. Over time, the chips grow together into a single block.
ðŸ“Œ Interesting point: bone chips can be taken from the patient's pelvis â€” there they are like a Â«spare partÂ».

description.professional:
Installation of screws into the vertebral pedicles (diameter 5.5-7.5 mm). Position control with a C-arm: the screw must pass through the pedicle without going beyond it. Installation of rods (diameter 5.5-6.5 mm) with compression. Fixation with contrast agents.
Instruments:
- Pedicle probes (gearshift)
- Stylet for thread cutting
- Torque wrench (1.5-2 Nm)
Technique:
1. Entry point: junction of transverse process and superior articular process.
2. Insertion angle: 5-10Â° medially in the lumbar region.
3. Depth: 80% of the pedicle length on the x-ray.
Logistics:
- Screw stability test (no Â«toggleÂ»).
Nuance: In osteoporosis - cement augmentation (PMMA).
description.normal:
The vertebrae are fastened with titanium screws and rods - like scaffolding.
ðŸ“Œ Important: screws are screwed into the strongest parts of the vertebra â€” the pedicles.

description.professional:
Decortical fusion of the remaining bone structures (arches, transverse processes) with a burr to stimulate fusion. Placing bone chips in the lateral grooves. If necessary, installing an interspinous stabilizer (e.g. Coflex).
Instruments:
- High-speed burr (Anspach)
- Bone forceps (Leksell)
- Bone cement syringe (for osteoporosis)
Technique:
1. Removing the cortical layer down to the spongy bone.
2. Formation of a Â«bedÂ» for the shavings between the transverse processes.
Logistics:
- The shavings are mixed with a collagen sponge (for fixation).
Nuance: With PLIF, the installation of interbody cages is mandatory paramedian.
description.normal:
The surgeon Â«scratchesÂ» the bone around to stimulate the growth of new tissue. Everything is sprinkled with bone shavings - like a fertilizer for fusion.
ðŸ“Œ Interesting point: sometimes an additional Â«springÂ» is placed between the spinous processes for unloading.

description.professional:
Hemostasis (Surgicel, Floseal). Drainage installation (2 drains with ALIF). Layered suturing: fascia (Vicryl 0), subcutaneous tissue (Vicryl 2-0), skin (monofilament 3-0). Application of a sterile dressing.
Instruments:
- Jackson-Pratt drain (10 Fr)
- Mathieu needle holder
- Absorbable suture material
Postoperative protocol:
1. Corset (TLSO) for 3 months.
2. Limitation of twisting/bending for 6 weeks.
3. CT control after 3/6/12 months.
Complications:
- Pseudoarthrosis (5-15%).
- Cage migration (3%).
- Neighboring segment syndrome (10% over 5 years).
description.normal:
The wound is sutured, leaving drains. After 1-2 days, the patient gets up in a corset.
ðŸ“Œ Good news: titanium structures last a lifetime - they do not need to be replaced!

modes.professional: Emergency surgical intervention to evacuate blood accumulation in the cranial cavity with brain decompression. Options: resection trepanation for intracerebral hematomas, osteoplastic trepanation for epi-/subdural hematomas. Critical control of the bleeding source (meningeal vessels, parenchymal arteries) and assessment of the dislocation of brain structures is precise.
modes.normal: Urgent surgery to remove a blood clot from the skull after trauma or stroke. The surgeon removes the blood clot that is pressing on the brain, saving the patient's life.

description.professional:
CT of the head without contrast (determination of the type of hematoma, volume, displacement of midline structures). Preparation of the operating room: neurosurgical kit, oscillatory saw, autotransfusion kit. Intubation, mechanical ventilation, correction of coagulopathy (vitamin K, FFP if INR> 1.5). Patient position depending on location: supine (frontal hematomas), lateral (temporal).
Instruments:
- Perfusion apparatus (Cell Saver)
- Neuronavigation (for elective cases)
- Emergency craniotomy kit
Technique:
1. Volume calculation using the ABC/2 formula (for intracerebral).
2. Hematoma projection marking using CT slices.
3. ICP monitoring (mannitol 1 g/kg for signs of dislocation).
Logistics:
- Simultaneous preparation of two surgical teams for bilateral hematomas.
Note: For a subdural hematoma with a thickness of >10 mm - emergency surgery within 4 hours.
description.normal:
The patient is immediately taken to a CT scan - the image will show where the blood has accumulated. In the operating room, instruments are prepared while the patient is anesthetized.
ðŸ“Œ Life fact: with an epidural hematoma, every minute counts - the Â«golden hourÂ» for surgery.

description.professional:
Linear skin incision (for epidural - above the injured artery, for subdural - a large arcuate one). Burr hole with a trepanner (1 cm below the lower edge of the hematoma). Expansion of the trepanation window to 5x5 cm with Kerrison nippers. For intracerebral hematoma - resection trepanation with removal of the bone flap.
Instruments:
- Oscillating saw (Anspach)
- Kerrison nippers (3-5 mm)
- Arc cutter (for bone flaps)
Technique:
1. In case of epidural hematoma - the first opening is above the site of the artery rupture (usually the middle meningeal).
2. In case of subdural - trepanation at the point of maximum clot thickness.
3. In case of intracerebral - trepanation above the projection of the hematoma + 2 cm.
Logistics:
- The bone flap during resection is stored in an antibiotic solution.
Nuance: In case of severe cerebral edema - the trepanation window is widened to 10 cm.
description.normal:
The surgeon cuts a Â«windowÂ» in the skull directly above the blood clot. In urgent operations, the bone may not be put back so that the brain can swell.
ðŸ“Œ Important: the size of the hole is like the palm of an adult.

description.professional:
Step-by-step removal of clots: for epidural - detachment from the dura mater with a raspatory, for subdural - irrigation and aspiration, for intracerebral - microsurgical technique with bipolar coagulation. Control of the source of bleeding: clipping of meningeal vessels, coagulation of parenchymal arteries.
Instruments:
- Aspirator with adjustable pressure (factory 200-300 mmHg)
- Bipolar forceps (Malis, 20 W)
- Microsurgical clips (Yasargil, 5 mm)
Technique:
1. Epidural: coagulation of the middle meningeal artery at the foramen spinosum.
2. Subdural: lavage of the cavity with warm saline until the water is clear.
3. Intracerebral: removal along the border with the edematous zone (without affecting the Â«penumbraÂ»).
Logistics:
- The volume of removed blood is measured for replenishment.
Nuance: In case of organized subdural hematoma - excision of the capsule.
description.normal:
The blood clot is removed with a special suction. The bleeding vessel is pressed or Â«gluedÂ». In case of intracerebral hemorrhages, they work like jewelers - under a microscope.
ðŸ“Œ Fact: old hematomas (2-3 weeks) become dense, like rubber - they are cut out in pieces.

description.professional:
Thorough hemostasis: Surgicel tamponade, bone wax for bleeding from diploic veins, fibrin glue (Tisseel) for parenchymal bleeding. In case of severe edema - durotomy with plastic surgery with autocartilage/artificial membrane. Drainage of the subdural space (Redon 10 Fr drainage).
Instruments:
- Hemostatic sponges (Surgicel, Floseal)
- Drainage system (Jackson-Pratt)
- Dural patches (DuraGen)
Technique:
1. Hemostasis control when blood pressure rises to 140 mm Hg.
2. Checking brain pulsation after hematoma removal.
3. If necessary - resection of non-viable brain tissue.
Logistics:
- Drainage is connected to a system with low negative pressure (50-70 mm Hg).
Nuance: In case of malignant edema - leaving a bone flap (decompressive hemicraniectomy).
description.normal:
Every drop of blood is stopped with special sponges. If the brain is very swollen - the membrane is expanded with a Â«patchÂ».
ðŸ“Œ Important: after removing the clot, the brain should start pulsating - this is a sign of success.

description.professional:
In osteoplastic trepanation - return of the bone flap with fixation with titanium plates. In decompressive - suturing of the dura mater without tension, suturing of the temporal muscle to the aponeurosis. Layered suturing of the wound: galea (Vicryl 0), subcutaneous tissue (Vicryl 3-0), skin (stapler/monofilament).
Instruments:
- Titanium microplates (1.5 mm)
- Stapling device (for skin)
- Castroviejo needle holder
Postoperative protocol:
1. CT control after 2 hours.
2. Maintaining SBP 120-140 mm Hg.
3. Prevention of seizures (levetiracetam).
Complications:
- Hematoma recurrence (5-15%).
- Posttraumatic hydrocephalus (10%).
- Epilepsy (20-30% with intracerebral hematomas).
description.normal:
The bone is returned to its place (if possible) and fixed with titanium plates. Neat stitches are applied to the skin. After 2 hours, a repeat CT scan will show whether new blood has accumulated.
ðŸ“Œ Good news: 70% of patients return to normal life after timely surgery!

modes.professional: Cardiac surgical replacement of a damaged heart valve with a mechanical or biological prosthesis. Access through sternotomy, connection of the ICC, excision of the native valve, fixation of the prosthesis, disconnection of the ICC with restoration of cardiac activity. Control of anticoagulation and prevention of embolism are critical.
modes.normal: Surgery to replace a Â«brokenÂ» heart valve with an artificial one. It is done through an incision in the sternum, connected to a heart-lung machine. After installing the valve, the heart is restarted. The patient lives with it for decades!

description.professional:
General anesthesia: induction (propofol + fentanyl), muscle relaxants (rocuronium), intubation. Installation of invasive monitoring (arterial line, CVC, TEE). Median sternotomy: incision from the jugular fossa to the xiphoid process, dissection of the sternum with an oscillating saw. Bone wax hemostasis.
Instruments:
- Oscillating saw (blade thickness 0.3 mm)
- Sternum retractor (Finochietto)
- EchoCG sensor (for valve monitoring)
Technique:
1. Incision of the skin and subcutaneous tissue with an electrocoagulator.
2. The sternum is sawed strictly along the midline, avoiding pleural cavities.
Logistics:
- Blood is aspirated into the Cell Saver system for reinfusion.
Nuance: For repeat surgeries, a cutter is used instead of a saw (risk of heart damage).
description.normal:
The patient is given general anesthesia, a breathing tube is inserted. The sternum is cut in the center - it's like Â«opening the doorÂ» to the heart.
ðŸ“Œ An interesting point: the bone is then fastened with titanium staples - they remain forever!

steps.name: Connection to the artificial blood vessel

description.professional:
Cannulation of the aorta and right atrium. Heparin administration (300-400 U/kg), ACT >480 sec. Connection to the artificial blood vessel (ABV). Cardioplegic solution (cold Custodiol or blood with potassium) to stop the heart.
Instruments:
- Aortic cannula 20-22 Fr
- Double-lumen venous catheter 32 Fr
- Cardioplegic system (Del Nido)
Technique:
1. The aorta is cannulated above the sinuses of Valsalva.
2. Venous drainage is through the right atrium.
3. Cardioplegia is introduced into the aortic root (antegrade) or coronary sinus (retrograde).
Logistics:
- Blood temperature control (28-32Â°C).
Nuance: In case of aortic calcification â€” axillary artery cannulation.
description.normal:
The heart is connected to an Â«artificial heartÂ» (ICC device), which will pump blood instead of it. The organ itself is stopped with a cold solution â€” as if Â«put to sleepÂ» for the duration of the operation.
ðŸ“Œ Important: such an operation cannot be performed without ICC!

description.professional:
Aortic/left atrium incision (for mitral valve). Excision of native valve leaflets, decalcification of the fibrous ring. Revision of subvalvular structures (chords, papillary muscles). Collection of material for histology.
Instruments:
- Mezzenbaum scissors (for aorta)
- Decorticator (for calcium)
- Pulse irrigator (saline + heparin)
Technique:
1. Aortic access: transverse incision 1 cm above the commissures.
2. Mitral access: through the interatrial septum or left atrium.
3. Calcium is removed sharply, avoiding perforation.
Logistics:
- Removed tissues sent for histology (to rule out endocarditis).
Nuance: In case of mitral stenosis, revision of the chords is mandatory.
description.normal:
The Surgeon opens the aorta or atrium, cuts out the old valve and cleans the area from calcium (like Â«scraping off scaleÂ»).
ðŸ“Œ Hard fact: calcium makes the valve stony - it must be removed completely!

description.professional:
Fixation of an artificial valve (mechanical/biological) with sutures (Ethibond 2-0) or rapid-deployment system. For mechanical - mandatory anticoagulation (INR 2.5-3.5). Checking the mobility of the leaflets, tightness.
Instruments:
- Prosthesis (e.g. Carpentier-Edwards or On-X)
- Needle holder (for circular suture)
- Leaflet tester (for mechanical valves)
Technique:
1. 12-20 separate sutures with gaskets (pledgets) are applied.
2. The prosthesis is Â«putÂ» in place, the knots are tightened.
3. Leak test - introduction of saline solution into the left ventricle.
Logistics:
- The valve size is determined by the template (sizer).
Nuance: If the aortic ring is small, plastic surgery (expansion) is possible.
description.normal:
A new valve (metal or animal tissue) is sewn with threads that do not dissolve. The mechanical one has clicks, the biological one lasts 10-15 years.
ðŸ“Œ Interesting point: the surgeon checks the valve by pouring water - like a plumber!

description.professional:
Aortic/atrial closure (Prolene 4-0). Decannulation of the ICC, administration of protamine (1:1 to heparin). Starting the heart with defibrillation (10-20 J) or adrenaline. Placement of drains (mediastinal + pericardial). Stitching the sternum with wire (6-8 staples).
Instruments:
- Defibrillator (internal electrodes)
- Blake drain 28 Fr
- Bone staples (titanium)
Technique:
1. EchoCG control for regurgitation/stenosis.
2. The sternum is fixed with double-twisted wire.
3. The subcutaneous tissue is sutured in layers.
Logistics:
- Check for bleeding before closure.
Postoperative protocol:
1. Mechanical ventilation for 2-6 hours.
2. Anticoagulants (warfarin for mechanical valves).
3. EchoCG before discharge.
Complications:
- Bleeding (5%).
- Conduction block (requires pacemaker).
- Endocarditis (1%).
description.normal:
The heart is started with a shock or medications. The sternum is secured with wire, drains are left for 1-2 days.
ðŸ“Œ Good news: modern valves last 20+ years, and patients live a full life!

modes.professional: Surgical removal of aortic aneurysm with replacement of the affected area with a synthetic prosthesis or endovascular stent graft. Access depends on the location (laparotomy/thoracotomy), control of the proximal and distal edges of the aneurysm, reimplantation of aortic branches is mandatory. Control of spinal cord and abdominal organ ischemia is critical.
modes.normal: An operation that saves from a Â«bombÂ» in the abdomen or chest - an aneurysm (a dangerous widening of the aorta). The surgeon either opens the abdomen/chest to replace the damaged area with an artificial tube, or inserts a stent through a puncture in the thigh. After this, the aorta becomes strong again and does not threaten to rupture.

description.professional:
General anesthesia: intubation anesthesia (propofol + fentanyl + muscle relaxants), invasive monitoring (arterial line, CVP, TEE). The patient is positioned on the back (for abdominal aneurysm) or on the side (for thoracoabdominal). Access: midline laparotomy (for infrarenal aneurysm) or left thoracotomy (for thoracic region).
Instruments:
- Electrocoagulator (Valleylab, 40 W)
- Retractor (Omni-Tract for laparotomy)
- Scalpel #20
Technique:
1. For abdominal access â€” incision from the xiphoid process to the pubis.
2. For thoracotomy â€” incision along the 6th intercostal space with dissection of the diaphragm.
Logistics:
- Preparation of the Cell Saver system for blood reinfusion.
Note: If the aneurysm ruptures â€” temporary clamping of the aorta until the abdominal cavity is opened.
description.normal:
The patient is sedated and connected to devices that monitor blood pressure and heart rate. The incision is made either in the center of the abdomen (if the aneurysm is in the abdominal aorta) or between the ribs (if in the thoracic aorta). It's like Â«opening the hoodÂ» to access the body's main Â«pipeÂ».
ðŸ“Œ Important: during an emergency operation (if the aneurysm is already rupturing), the surgeon can clamp the aorta before the incision - to stop catastrophic bleeding.

description.professional:
Isolation of the aorta proximal and distal to the aneurysm. Clamping with DeBakey or Satinsky clamps. In case of infrarenal aneurysm - control of the renal arteries. Administration of heparin (5000 IU intravenously). In case of thoracoabdominal aneurysm - reimplantation of the intercostal arteries for prevention of spinal cord ischemia.
Instruments:
- Vascular clamps (DeBakey, Fogarty)
- Penfield dissector No. 4
- Ultrasound Doppler (to assess blood flow)
Technique:
1. Proximal clamping - below the celiac trunk (for infrarenal aneurysm).
2. Distal - above the bifurcation (for a tubular prosthesis) or on the iliac arteries (for a bifurcation one).
Logistics:
- The clamping time should not exceed 30 minutes (risk of kidney/intestinal ischemia).
Nuance: In case of aortic calcification - careful application of clamps to avoid plaque fragmentation.
description.normal:
The surgeon finds healthy areas of the aorta above and below the aneurysm and applies Â«clampsÂ» to them - like shutting off water before repairing a pipe. If the aneurysm is close to the kidneys, their arteries are also carefully protected.
ðŸ“Œ Interesting point: during surgery on the thoracic aorta, small arteries that feed the spinal cord can be sewn up to avoid paralysis!

description.professional:
Longitudinal aortotomy, removal of thrombotic masses and calcifications. Resection of the aneurysm wall while preserving the posterior semicircle (with open technique). Anastomosis: proximal (end-to-end) and distal (end-to-end or bifurcation prosthesis). Suture material - prolene 3-0 or 4-0.
Instruments:
- Vascular prosthesis (Dacron, diameter 16-22 mm)
- Castroviejo needle holder
- Suture pads (pledgets) to strengthen anastomoses
Technique:
1. The prosthesis is sutured with a continuous suture to the proximal edge of the aorta.
2. The distal anastomosis is formed after decompression (removal of air/thrombi).
3. With a bifurcation prosthesis, it is sequentially sutured to the iliac arteries.
Logistics:
- Checking the tightness of the anastomoses with an injection of heparinized saline.
Nuance: With endovascular stenting (EVAR) - access through the femoral arteries and installation of the stent graft under X-ray control.
description.normal:
The aneurysm is opened, blood clots and calcium are removed (like Â«cleaning a blockageÂ»). An artificial Â«tubeÂ» made of durable material (Dacron) is sewn in its place. If the aneurysm is large, a Â«teeÂ» with branches for the iliac arteries is installed.
ðŸ“Œ A visual moment: the prosthesis is sewn on so tightly that the surgeon checks the stitches by pouring saline solution in â€” like looking for a leak in a bicycle tube!

steps.name: Reimplantation of branches and restoration of blood flow

description.professional:
For thoracoabdominal aneurysms â€” reimplantation of the celiac trunk, superior mesenteric and renal arteries into the prosthesis (the Â«islandÂ» technique or separate anastomoses). Decompression of the aorta before removing the clamps. Control of distal blood flow with Doppler.
Instruments:
- Bulb aspirator (to remove air emboli)
- Vascular clips (Hem-o-lok)
- Thermography (to assess organ perfusion)
Technique:
1. Sequential opening of clamps: first proximal, then distal.
2. In EVAR â€” control of the stent graft position on angiography.
Logistics:
- Renal ischemia time â€” no more than 40 minutes.
Nuance: In case of stent Â«leakageÂ» (endoleak) â€” installation of additional components or conversion to open surgery.
description.normal:
If the aneurysm has affected the arteries that feed the intestines or kidneys, they are Â«transplantedÂ» into a new prosthesis. Blood flow is restored in stages: first the Â«upperÂ» clamp is opened, then the Â«lowerÂ» ones.
ðŸ“Œ Life hack: surgeons use ultrasound to make sure blood is flowing to all organs - like a plumber checks the water pressure!

description.professional:
Hemostasis (Surgicel, TachoSil), drainage (Jackson-Pratt drainage). Layer-by-layer suturing of the laparotomy/thoracotomy wound. For EVAR - removal of introducers and suturing of femoral approaches. Intraoperative angiography or ultrasound to exclude endoleaks.
Instruments:
- 28 Fr drainage
- Suture material (PDS for aponeurosis, Monocryl for skin)
- Angiograph (for EVAR)
Postoperative protocol:
1. CT angiography after 24 hours.
2. Monitoring of diuresis, intestinal ischemia markers (lactate).
3. Lifelong observation (in case of EVAR â€” annual CT).
Complications:
- Spinal cord ischemia (paralysis â€” 5-10% in thoracoabdominal aneurysms).
- Prosthesis thrombosis (1-3%).
- Endolitis (stent leakage â€” 15-20%).
description.normal:
After checking the sutures for leaks, the wound is sutured, leaving drains. If the surgery was endovascular (through punctures), only a small suture will remain on the thigh.
ðŸ“Œ Important: even after a successful surgery, the patient regularly undergoes CT scans to make sure that the aneurysm is not Â«leakingÂ». Modern stents require lifelong monitoring!

modes.professional: Radical pericardial removal in constrictive pericarditis or recurrent effusions. Access: median sternotomy or left thoracotomy. Steps: cardiac mobilization, layer-by-layer excision of the pericardium while preserving the phrenic nerves, hemostasis control. Control of right ventricular function after decompression is critical.
modes.normal: An operation to free the heart from its Â«shellÂ» - a thickened or inflamed sac around the heart (pericardium). The surgeon carefully removes the dense membrane from the heart that prevents it from beating normally. After this, the heart can again freely fill with blood and function fully.

description.professional:
General anesthesia: intubation (double-lumen tube during thoracotomy), invasive monitoring (arterial line, central venous pressure, transesophageal echocardiography). Position: supine (for sternotomy) or on the right side (for thoracotomy). Access: median sternotomy (more common) or left thoracotomy (5th intercostal space).
Instruments:
- Oscillating saw (for sternotomy)
- Retractor (Finochietto for thoracotomy)
- Electrocoagulator (Valleylab, 30 W)
Technique:
1. For sternotomy - incision from the jugular fossa to the xiphoid process.
2. In thoracotomy - an incision from the parasternal line to the mid-axillary line.
Logistics:
- Preparing the Cell Saver system for blood reinfusion.
Nuance: In previous surgeries - using an ultrasonic scalpel (Harmonic).
description.normal:
The patient is sedated and connected to a ventilator. The surgeon makes an incision either in the center of the sternum (as in bypass surgery) or between the ribs on the left. This is like opening a Â«doorÂ» to the heart to get to its dense membrane.
ðŸ“Œ Important: if the patient has had previous heart surgeries, the surgeon acts especially carefully - like a sapper defusing a mine.

steps.name: Opening the pericardium and mobilizing the heart

description.professional:
Identification and preservation of the phrenic nerves. Longitudinal opening of the pericardium in the avascular zone. Gradual separation of the pericardium from the epicardium: first on the anterior surface, then laterally. In case of constrictive pericarditis - excision of calcified areas.
Instruments:
- Metzenbaum scissors
- Penfield dissector #4
- Ultrasonic scissors (Harmonic)
Technique:
1. Initial pericardial incision - 2 cm above the diaphragm.
2. Mobilization from the left ventricle to the right (to avoid overloading the RV).
3. In case of dense adhesions - sharp dissection method.
Logistics:
- Marking the phrenic nerve with a silicone loop.
Nuance: In case of damage to the coronary arteries - immediate suturing with 6-0 Prolene.
description.normal:
The surgeon finds and carefully moves aside the nerve that controls the diaphragm (so that the patient can breathe normally after the surgery). Then he begins to remove the pericardium from the heart - like peeling an orange, peeling it slice by slice.
ðŸ“Œ Interesting point: they always start from the left side - if they start from the right, the suddenly freed heart may not cope with the load!

description.professional:
Excision of the pericardium: anteriorly - from the aortic root to the diaphragm, posteriorly - to the pulmonary veins, laterally - to the phrenic nerves. In constrictive pericarditis - complete removal (including the diaphragmatic surface). Hemostasis with bipolar (15 W).
Instruments:
- DeBakey forceps
- Bipolar coagulation (Malis)
- Vascular clips (Hem-o-lok)
Technique:
1. Sequential separation of the pericardium by blunt and sharp means.
2. Special attention is paid to the areas of the atrial appendages and vena cava.
3. Myocardial bleeding control - Surgicel tamponade.
Logistics:
- The removed pericardium is sent for histology.
Nuance: During tamponade - preliminary puncture of the pericardium to stabilize hemodynamics.
description.normal:
The surgeon removes the pericardium from all sides of the heart - from the front, back and sides, leaving only small areas near important vessels. This is similar to removing the wrapper from a ball that has dried and prevents it from inflating.
ðŸ“Œ Important: when the last section is removed, the heart immediately begins to beat more freely - doctors literally see how it breathes a sigh of relief.

description.professional:
Thorough hemostasis of the pericardial bed (Surgicel, TachoSil). Installation of drains: into the pericardial cavity (24 Fr) and pleural cavity (during thoracotomy). Checking the integrity of the phrenic nerves. Leak test with increased pressure in the breathing circuit.
Instruments:
- Blake drain
- Hemostatic sponges (Floseal)
- Nerve stimulator (to check the diaphragm)
Technique:
1. Washing the cavity with warm saline.
2. Checking the diaphragm excursion during nerve stimulation.
3. The drainage is fixed to the skin with a separate suture.
Logistics:
- Counting napkins and instruments before closing.
Nuance: If the pleura is damaged, additional drainage is installed.
description.normal:
After removing the pericardium, the surgeon carefully checks for bleeding areas on the heart (using special Â«patchesÂ» made of absorbable cellulose). Then he places drainage tubes - one will drain fluid from the pericardium, the other (if access was through the chest) - from the pleural cavity.
ðŸ“Œ A visual moment: to check if the diaphragm nerve is damaged, the surgeon can lightly Â«tickleÂ» it with an electrical stimulator - the diaphragm twitches, as if from hiccups!

description.professional:
Layer-by-layer suturing: sternum - with steel wires (for sternotomy), muscles - Vicryl 0, subcutaneous tissue - Vicryl 2-0, skin - with 3-0 monofilament. For thoracotomy - suturing of intercostal muscles leaving drainage.
Instruments:
- Bone nippers (for sternum modeling)
- Wire (5-6 staples for sternotomy)
- Suture material (PDS, Monocryl)
Postoperative protocol:
1. Mechanical ventilation for 2-4 hours (with stable hemodynamics).
2. Monitoring of central venous pressure and diuresis (risk of acute right ventricular failure).
3. EchoCG after 24 hours to assess function heart.
Complications:
- Acute heart failure (15-20%).
- Bleeding (3-5%).
- Â«Free heartÂ» syndrome (hyperdynamic function - rare).
description.normal:
The sternum is fastened with titanium staples (which remain forever), the muscles and skin are sutured with absorbable threads. After the operation, the patient is left on a ventilator for several hours until the heart adapts to the new state.
ðŸ“Œ Amazing fact: sometimes the heart, freed from the squeezing Â«shellÂ», begins to work too actively - this is called Â«free heart syndromeÂ», and doctors are prepared for such a development of events.

modes.professional: Surgical or endovascular correction of a congenital defect in the septum between the atria. Options: open surgery on a stopped heart with patch plasty (auto- or synthetic) or endovascular installation of an occluder (Amplatzer, Gore Cardioform). Control of the defect edges and prevention of embolism are critical.
modes.normal: Surgery to Â«patch a holeÂ» in the wall between the upper chambers of the heart. In children and adults, the defect can be closed either through an incision in the chest or through a puncture in the thigh - without opening the heart! After this, the blood stops mixing, and the heart works like new.

description.professional:
**Open method**: Median sternotomy, connection to the ICC. **Endovascular method**: access through the femoral vein, passing a catheter into the right atrium. Intraoperative TEE to measure the size of the ASD and assess the edges.
Instruments:
- Sternotome (for open access)
- Introducer 10-12 Fr (for endovascular)
- TEE sensor
Technique:
1. With open access - cannulation of the aorta and vena cava.
2. With endovascular - angiography to visualize the defect.
Logistics:
- For the endovascular method: selection of an occluder 2-4 mm larger than the diameter ASD.
Nuance: If the margins are insufficient (<5 mm) â€” only open surgery.
description.normal:
**If the surgery is open**: The surgeon cuts the sternum and connects the patient to the artificial blood circulation machine (ACM). **If the method is endovascular**: A thin tube (catheter) is inserted through a puncture in the groin and carried to the heart.
ðŸ“Œ Interesting: the size of the Â«holeÂ» is measured with ultrasound right during the surgery â€” like a tailor takes measurements!

steps.name: Visualization and assessment of the defect

description.professional:
In case of open surgery: opening the right atrium, revision of the ASD (localization, size, presence of the inferior vena cava valve). In case of endovascular surgery: control of the position of the conductor through the defect into the left atrium (the Â«loopÂ» technique).
Instruments:
- Cardioscope (for open access)
- Angiograph (for endovascular)
- Measuring balloons (for sizing)
Technique:
1. In case of secundum ASD - assessment of the distance to the aorta, pulmonary veins.
2. In case of sinus venosus type - planning of reimplantation of the pulmonary veins.
Logistics:
- Stock of occluders of different sizes (+ reserve method).
Nuance: In case of multiple defects - combined strategy.
description.normal:
The surgeon examines the Â«holeÂ»: if it is small (up to 30 mm) and located in the center, an occluder can be placed through a catheter. If the edges are thin or the defect is of a complex shape, an open operation with a patch will be required.
ðŸ“Œ Important: sometimes there is more than one Â«holeÂ» - then they close everything, like patches!

description.professional:
**Open method**: Excision of the ASD edges, suturing (for defects <10 mm) or pericardial/PTFE patch plasty (5-0 Prolene suture). **Endovascular**: delivery of the occluder through a catheter, sequential opening of the discs in the left and right atria.
Instruments:
- Amplatzer Septal occluder
- Castroviejo needle holder (for open)
- Delivery Sheath
Technique:
1. For open surgery â€” continuous suture with pledgets.
2. In case of endovascular â€” control of the occluder position on echocardiography before release.
Logistics:
- Stability test: slight twitching of the occluder with a catheter.
Nuance: In case of primary ASD (AV canal) â€” only open plastic surgery.
description.normal:
**Open method**: The surgeon stitches up the hole with a strong thread (like darning socks) or sews on a patch of pericardial tissue. **Endovascular**: an Â«umbrellaÂ» is inserted through the catheter â€” it opens on both sides of the septum, tightly sealing the defect.
ðŸ“Œ Visual moment: the occluder resembles two mesh Â«platesÂ» that press the hole from both sides!

description.professional:
Tightness check: in case of open surgery â€” injection of saline into the left atrium, in case of endovascular surgery â€” transesophageal echocardiography with contrast. Removal of air from the heart cavities. Drainage (with open access). Suturing wounds.
Instruments:
- Contrast agent (for echocardiography)
- Needle for air aspiration
- Redon 16 Fr drainage
Technique:
1. In case of open surgery â€” suturing the atrium with a double-row suture.
2. In endovascular surgery â€” removal of the delivery system.
Logistics:
- X-ray control of the occluder position before completion.
Nuance: Additional correction in case of residual shunt.
description.normal:
The surgeon checks for leaks: in open surgery, he pours saline into the heart (like looking for a hole in a bicycle tube), in endovascular surgery, he does an ultrasound with contrast.
ðŸ“Œ Important: if the Â«umbrellaÂ» is not positioned correctly, it can be adjusted or even replaced!

description.professional:
**Open surgery**: mechanical ventilation for 2-4 hours, drainage monitoring, echocardiography after 24 hours. **Endovascular**: activation after 6 hours, echocardiography before discharge. Antiplatelet agents (aspirin 3-6 months).
Postoperative protocol:
1. In case of open surgery â€” corset for 1 month (for sternum fusion).
2. ECG monitoring (risk of blockade in case of marginal defect).
3. Repeated echocardiography after 1, 6 and 12 months.
Complications:
- Residual shunt (5% in case of endovascular method).
- Occluder embolization (0.5%).
- Atrial fibrillation (10-15% in adults).
description.normal:
After open surgery, the patient spends 1-2 days in intensive care, after endovascular surgery â€” gets up in the evening! Â«ThinningÂ» tablets are prescribed for 6 months (to prevent blood clots from forming on the occluder).
ðŸ“Œ Good news: children after such an operation run around a week later as if nothing had happened!

modes.professional: Surgical installation of a pacemaker (pacemaker) to correct bradyarrhythmia. Stages: access to the subclavian vein, insertion of electrodes into the heart cavity, formation of a subcutaneous bed for the generator, testing of stimulation parameters. Control of the position of the electrodes and the stimulation threshold is critical.
modes.normal: Through a small incision under the collarbone, thin wires are inserted into the heart, and a Â«batteryÂ» is implanted under the skin. It sends impulses if the heart beats abnormally. The operation is almost painless and the patient can go home the next day.

description.professional:
Treatment of the surgical field (left/right subclavian region) with chlorhexidine 2%. Local anesthesia: infiltration of lidocaine 1% with adrenaline (1:100,000). ECG monitoring (leads II and V1), non-invasive blood pressure, pulse oximetry. Antibiotic prophylaxis (cefazolin 1 g IV 30 min before incision).
Instruments:
- Syringe 10 ml with needle 22G (lidocaine)
- Antiseptic wipes
- ECG electrodes
Technique:
1. Infiltration of the skin and subcutaneous tissue along the line of the future incision.
2. Monitoring the heart rate and rhythm on the monitor.
Logistics:
- Used needles - in a container for sharp objects.
Nuance: In case of allergy to lidocaine - articaine 4%.
description.normal:
The patient is placed on his back, the skin below the collarbone is treated with Â«iodineÂ». Several injections with anesthetic are given - the area will go numb. Sensors are glued to the chest to monitor the heartbeat.
ðŸ“Œ Interesting point: if the patient is worried, they can give a sedative, but more often everything goes without it - it will not hurt!

description.professional:
Puncture of the subclavian vein with an 18G needle using the Seldinger method (angle 30Â° to the skin, direction to the sternoclavicular joint). Checking the aspiration of venous blood. Insertion of a 0.035 inch guidewire under fluoroscopic control. Tissue expansion with a 7 Fr. dilator. Installing the introducer.
Instruments:
- Vein puncture needle (18G, 70 mm long)
- 0.035 J-type guidewire
- Dilator with 7 Fr introducer
- Fluoroscopic apparatus (C-arm)
Technique:
1. Vein puncture 1 cm below the collarbone.
2. The guidewire is advanced to the superior vena cava (ECG or X-ray control).
Logistics:
- Checking the free movement of the guidewire before dilation.
Nuance: If unsuccessful, alternative access is through the axillary vein.
description.normal:
Through a tiny puncture under the collarbone, the doctor inserts a thin Â«wireÂ» into the vein and advances it toward the heart. Everything is controlled by X-ray in real time.
ðŸ“Œ Interesting point: the patient does not feel how the conductor moves through the vein - veins do not have pain receptors!

description.professional:
Inserting stimulating electrodes through the introducer: ventricular (into the right ventricle) and atrial (into the right atrium). Fixation with an active (screw) or passive (with Â«antennaeÂ») mechanism. Fluoroscopic control of position (ventricular electrode - at the apex, atrial - in the atrial appendage).
Instruments:
- Ventricular electrode (e.g. Medtronic 4076)
- Atrial electrode (e.g. Medtronic 4574)
- Stylet for shaping the electrode
- Stimulation threshold meter
Technique:
1. The ventricular electrode is inserted through the tricuspid valve.
2. The atrial electrode is bent in the shape of Â«JÂ».
Logistics:
- Testing the electrodes before fixation.
Nuance: In case of atrial fibrillation - only the ventricular electrode (VVI mode).
description.normal:
Through a tube in a vein, the doctor passes thin wires into the heart: one into the upper chamber (atrium), the other into the lower (ventricle). The tips of the electrodes Â«catchÂ» the wall of the heart.
ðŸ“Œ Interesting point: the wires are flexible, like spaghetti, but their position is checked with an X-ray - so that everything is perfect!

description.professional:
Measuring the stimulation threshold (voltage at which the heart responds with contraction), impedance (resistance) and sensitivity (registration of its own rhythm). Optimal parameters: threshold <1.0 V, impedance 300-1000 Ohm, sensitivity >2.0 mV. Correction of the electrode position if the values are unsatisfactory.
Tools:
- ECG analyzer (e.g. Medtronic 2290)
- Temporary external stimulator
- Testing cables
Technique:
1. Stimulation with a gradual decrease in voltage until capture is lost.
2. Sensitivity testing in the Â«demandÂ» mode.
Logistics:
- Recording the parameters in the protocol.
Nuance: At a high threshold â€” replacing the electrode or choosing a new fixation location.
description.normal:
The doctor turns on the stimulator and checks how the heart responds to weak impulses. The screen shows that the heart Â«listensÂ» to the device.
ðŸ“Œ Interesting point: if the parameters are not ideal, the electrode will be adjusted a little - it's like adjusting an antenna for a clear signal!

steps.name: Formation of the bed and fixation of the generator

description.professional:
Formation of a subcutaneous pocket for the generator between the pectoralis major and deltoid muscles. Hemostasis by bipolar coagulation. Fixation of electrodes to the generator (screw connection). Placing the generator in the pocket, layer-by-layer suturing of the wound.
Instruments:
- Pocket clamp (metal retractor)
- Bipolar coagulator (15 W)
- Suture material (Vicryl 2-0 - fascia, Monocryl 4-0 - skin)
Technique:
1. The pocket is created bluntly (with a clamp or finger).
2. The generator is fixed to the muscle with a suture (Prolene 2-0).
Logistics:
- Check for the absence of bending of the electrodes.
Nuance: With thin skin - placement of the generator under the muscle.
description.normal:
A Â«pocketÂ» is formed under the skin below the collarbone, where the stimulator itself is placed - a flat box the size of a matchbox. The wires are connected to it, like cords to a TV. The incision is stitched up - the seam is almost invisible.
ðŸ“Œ Interesting point: you can feel the generator with your hand, but it does not even interfere with sleeping on this side!

description.professional:
Fluoroscopic control of the position of the electrodes and the generator. Application of an aseptic dressing. Activation of the pacemaker in DDD mode (or VVI in AF). Prescription of antibiotics (cefazolin 1 g Ã—2 days), pain relief (paracetamol 500 mg).
Instruments:
- Fluoroscopy in two projections (AP + lateral)
- Pacemaker programmer (for setting parameters)
- Sensor for checking the generator operation
Postoperative protocol:
1. X-ray control after 24 hours.
2. Limitation of arm movements for 7 days.
3. Sutures are removed on the 10th day.
Complications:
- Hematoma of the bed (3-5%).
- Dislocation electrode (1-2%).
- Infection (0.5-1%).
description.normal:
They do a final x-ray to make sure everything is in place. They put a bandage on and give you a reminder: don't raise your arm for a week, avoid magnets. In a month, the pacemaker is checked.
ðŸ“Œ Good news: modern pacemakers work for 8-10 years, and replacement is even easier than the first installation!

modes.professional: Replacement of the recipient's damaged heart with a donor organ. Stages: donor heart collection (conditioning, cardioplegia, excision), transportation in preservative solution, recipient preparation (sternotomy, ICC connection), orthotopic implantation (biatrial or bicaval anastomosis), heart start-up. Critical: ischemia time (<4 h), ABO compatibility, HLA typing, rejection prevention.
modes.normal: The most complex Â«heart repairÂ»: the diseased organ is replaced with a healthy one from a donor. The operation lasts 6-8 hours, requires perfect coordination between surgeons, anesthesiologists and transplantologists. A new heart begins to beat in the patient's chest, giving him a second chance at life.

description.professional:
Donor stage: After confirmation of donor brain death, hemodynamic support is provided (norepinephrine, vasopressin). Laparotomy/sternotomy. Heparin administration (300 U/kg). Canification of the aorta and pulmonary artery. Infusion of cardioplegic solution (Custodiol HTK or Stanford) at t=4Â°C. Cardiac excision: intersection of the superior/inferior vena cava, aorta, pulmonary veins. Immersion of the organ in a sterile container with preservative solution and ice.
Instruments:
- Cardioplegic solution (1000 ml)
- 14 Fr catheters (aorta, PA)
- Metzenbaum scissors for cutting vessels
- Thermally insulated container (with t-sensor)
Technique:
1. The aorta is clamped, cardioplegia is introduced into the aortic root.
2. The heart is removed with the Â«cuffÂ» from the atria and great vessels.
3. Time from circulatory arrest to extraction â€” <30 min.
Logistics:
- The container is marked with: blood type, donor weight, collection time.
Note: For long-distance transport, a perfusion machine (OCS Heart) is used.
description.normal:
The heart is taken from a donor who has been declared brain dead, but the body is supported by machines. Surgeons inject a special Â«preservativeÂ» into the organ, stop it and carefully extract it. The heart is placed on ice and urgently taken to the recipient's hospital - every minute counts!
ðŸ“Œ Hard fact: no more than 4 hours for the whole thing, otherwise the organ will die.

description.professional:
Recipient: Median sternotomy. Insertion of catheters into the aorta and vena cava. Connection to the artificial blood circulation (ABG) machine. Maintenance of hypothermia (28â€“32Â°C). Removal of the affected heart: transection of the aorta, PA, atria (leaving the posterior walls for anastomoses). Bed hemostasis.
Instruments:
- Oscillating saw (for the sternum)
- Cannulas for ABG (24 Fr â€” aorta, 32 Fr â€” vena cavae)
- Scalpel No. 20 + Potts scissors
Technique:
1. Anastomosis of the superior/inferior vena cavae to the ABG cannulas.
2. Resection of the recipient heart, preservation of the atrial appendages.
3. Antifibrinolytic therapy (tranexamic acid).
Logistics:
- Parallel monitoring of the donor heart (telephone communication with the transport team).
Nuance: In case of pulmonary hypertension - risk of acute right ventricular failure.
description.normal:
While the donor heart is on the way, the patient is prepared: the sternum is cut, connected to the device that replaces the heart and lungs. The diseased heart is carefully cut out, leaving only the Â«pocketsÂ» of the atria - a new one will be sewn to them later.
ðŸ“Œ Interesting point: the body is cooled to 28Â°C - this slows down the metabolism and protects the organs.

description.professional:
Biatrial method (Shumway): Anastomosis of the donor's left atrium to the recipient's atrial remnant with a continuous suture (Prolene 4-0). Then the right atrium. Anastomosis of the aorta and pulmonary artery. Deaeration through a puncture in the aorta. Gradual disconnection of the ICC.
Instruments:
- Prolene 4-0 suture material (with atraumatic needle)
- Atrium holders (Satinsky)
- Irrigator with warm saline
Technique:
1. Left atrial anastomosis is the first (most important).
2. The aorta is connected end-to-end (check for leaks).
3. Starting the heart: defibrillation (10â€“20 J) or spontaneous rhythm.
Logistics:
- The ischemia time of the donor heart should be <240 min.
Nuance: If the sizes do not match, pericardial adaptation or atrial plastic surgery.
description.normal:
The new heart is sewn on Â«in partsÂ»: first the left atrium, then the right, then the aorta and pulmonary artery. After the last suture, the organ is filled with blood, removing air bubbles. Then comes the moment of truth: the heart is started with an electric shock or it â€œcomes to lifeâ€ on its own.
ðŸ“Œ An exciting moment: the first contraction of the donor heart in the new chest - the surgeons freeze, watching the rhythm.

description.professional:
Hemodynamic control: Inotropic support (epinephrine 0.05 mcg / kg / min, milrinone). EchoCG assessment of contractility, exclusion of right ventricular hypertrophy. Installation of temporary epicardial electrodes for stimulation. Mediastinal drainage (2 drains). Sternum suturing with wire (Steel 5).
Instruments:
- EchoCG sensor (via esophagus)
- Pleurovac 28 Fr drains
- Bone wax for hemostasis
Technique:
1. Gradual reduction of ICC flow with stable BP.
2. In case of right ventricular failure â€” NO inhalation.
3. Rejection prevention: methylprednisolone 500 mg IV.
Logistics:
- Myocardial biopsy after 7 days (rejection assessment).
Note: In case of bleeding â€” protamine sulfate administration (1 mg per 100 U of heparin).
description.normal:
The heart is neglected, but the patient is not yet safe. Doctors adjust the medications so that the organ takes root, install drains to drain fluid, and stitch the sternum with titanium wire.
ðŸ“Œ Important: the first day is in intensive care, where blood pressure, rhythm, and oxygen levels are checked every 30 minutes.

description.professional:
Days 1â€“3: mechanical ventilation, monitoring of central venous pressure, diuresis, and troponin. Immunosuppression (tacrolimus, mycophenolate mofetil). Infection prevention (cefepime + fluconazole).
7 days: Endomyocardial biopsy (catheter through the jugular vein). Adjustment of immunosuppressant doses.
1 month: Assessment of cardiac function (EchoCG, MRI), transition to oral medications.
Complications:
- Acute rejection (15â€“20% in the first year).
- Infections (cytomegalovirus, fungi).
- Coronary artery disease of the donor heart (after 5 years).
Instruments:
- Endomyocardial biopsy biopsy
- Immunosuppressive monitors (tacrolimus blood levels)
Nuance: Lifelong ban on grapefruit (interacts with tacrolimus).
description.normal:
The first days are in intensive care: the heart Â«gets usedÂ» to the new body, and the patient receives shock doses of anti-rejection drugs. A week later - a biopsy: a tiny piece of the heart is taken through a vein in the neck to check if the body is attacking it.
ðŸ“Œ Hard and fast rule: always take pills now and avoid grapefruits (they ruin the medicine!)

modes.professional: Surgical elimination of atrial fibrillation (AF) by creating linear scar blocks in the myocardium of the atria to interrupt pathological electrical re-entry circuits. Options: classic Â«cut-sutureÂ» (Cox-Maze III) or ablation methods (radiofrequency, cryo-, laser). Stages: access through median sternotomy/thoracoscopy, isolation of pulmonary veins, creation of ablation lines, suturing of the left atrial appendage. Control of impulse conduction and prevention of thromboembolism are critical.
modes.normal: An operation that Â«draws a mazeÂ» on the heart so that chaotic electrical signals during atrial fibrillation can no longer run through the atria. After this, the heart beats evenly again. Often done simultaneously with valve replacement or bypass.

description.professional:
General anesthesia: induction with propofol (2 mg/kg), fentanyl (5 mcg/kg), muscle relaxant (rocuronium 0.6 mg/kg). Intubation, mechanical ventilation with PEEP 5 cm H2O. Monitoring: invasive BP, TEE, 12-lead ECG. Access: median sternotomy (when combined with other surgeries) or right mini-thoracotomy (for isolated MAZE).
Instruments:
- Oscillating saw (for the sternum)
- 5 mm thoracoscopic ports (for mini-access)
- Transesophageal echocardiogram sensor
Technique:
1. With sternotomy - cannulation of the aorta and vena cava for ICC.
2. With thoracoscopy - one-lung ventilation (collapse of the right lung).
Logistics:
- ECG electrodes are applied taking into account future ablation lines.
Nuance: With COPD, the time of one-lung ventilation is minimized.
description.normal:
The patient is sedated, a tube is inserted into the trachea for breathing. If the operation is combined with valve replacement, the sternum is cut; if MAZE is done separately, a small incision is made under the right armpit.
ðŸ“Œ Interesting point: during the operation, the heart can be stopped and connected to a heart-lung machine (CLM).

description.professional:
Longitudinal dissection of the pericardium in front of the phrenic nerve. Canification aortic (22 Fr cannula) and vena cava (32 Fr double-lumen cannula). Clamping of the aorta, introduction of crystalloid cardioplegia (4Â°C) into the aortic root. Myocardial temperature <15Â°C. Additionally: injection of cardioplegia into the coronary sinus (retrograde).
Instruments:
- Aortic clamp (Fogarty)
- 9 Fr cardioplegic catheter (for the coronary sinus)
- Myocardial temperature sensor
Technique:
1. Cardioplegia is introduced under a pressure of 200â€“300 mmHg.
2. Ischemia monitoring: ECG in ST-analysis mode.
Logistics:
- Every 20 minutes â€” repeat dose of cardioplegia.
Nuance: In case of left ventricular hypertrophy â€” add lidocaine to cardioplegia.
description.normal:
The heart is freed from the outer shell (pericardium), connected to the ICC apparatus and an Â«iceÂ» solution is administered to stop it. This gives the surgeon time for precision work.
ðŸ“Œ Important: the heart Â«sleepsÂ» for no more than 90 minutes - otherwise the risk of damage increases.

description.professional:
Classic MAZE (scissors-suture):
- Incisions in the left/right atria according to the Cox-Maze III scheme.
- Suturing with a continuous suture (Prolene 4-0) with the creation of electrical barriers.
Ablative methods:
- Radiofrequency (RF, 60â€“80Â°C): bipolar clamp (AtriCure) around the pulmonary veins.
- Cryoablation (-60Â°C, 2 min): CryoFlex probe (Medtronic) on the posterior wall of the left atrium.
Required lines:
1. Pulmonary vein isolation (circular).
2. Line from left appendage to mitral valve.
3. Line in right atrium (interatrial septum).
Instruments:
- Bipolar ablator (eg, AtriCure Gemini)
- Cryoprobe (eg, Medtronic CryoConsole)
- 4-0 PTFE suture (for appendage isolation)
Technique:
1. Ablation is performed until local biopotential drops to <0.1 mV.
2. Block test: atrial stimulation to confirm isolation.
Logistics:
- Ablation map (documentation of all lines).
Nuance: In case of persistent AF â€” additional ablation of the autonomic ganglia.
description.normal:
The surgeon Â«drawsÂ» a network of lines on the atria using freezing (cryo) or heating (radiofrequency). These scars become walls that block chaotic impulses. The pulmonary vein orifices are necessarily isolated â€” this is the main source of failures!
ðŸ“Œ Interesting point: the lines look like a maze â€” hence the name of the operation.

description.professional:
Resection or occlusion of the left atrial (LA) appendage to prevent thromboembolism. Methods:
- Suture: Double PTFE 4-0 suture with intussusception of the auricle.
- Clipping: Installation of a titanium clip (AtriClip).
- Stapling device: Stapler 45 mm (for thoracoscopy).
Instruments:
- Stapling device (eg, Endo GIA)
- Atraumatic clamp (for fixing the auricle)
Technique:
1. Before suturing - aspiration of blood from the auricle to exclude blood clots.
2. Checking the tightness of the suture using TEE.
Logistics:
- The removed auricle is sent for histology.
Nuance: In case of a blood clot in the auricle - preliminary anticoagulation (heparin).
description.normal:
The LA auricle is a Â«sacÂ» where blood clots often form during AF. It is either sutured or cut off to reduce the risk of stroke.
ðŸ“Œ Important: after the surgery, the patient still takes anticoagulants temporarily - the heart needs to heal.

description.professional:
Deaeration through a puncture in the aorta. Removal of the aortic clamp. Starting the heart: defibrillation (10-20 J) or spontaneous restoration of rhythm. Inotropic support (dobutamine 5 mcg / kg / min). Evaluation of sinus rhythm by ECG. Installation of temporary epicardial electrodes. Drainage of the mediastinum. Sternum suturing (Steel 5 wire) or thoracotomy access.
Instruments:
- Defibrillator with internal plates
- Epicardial electrodes (eg Medtronic 6500)
- Pleurovac 28 Fr drainage
Technique:
1. In case of AF after start-up â€” cardioversion 50â€“100 J.
2. Test for conductivity of ablation lines (atrial stimulation).
Logistics:
- Inotropes are administered through a central venous catheter.
Nuance: In case of pulmonary edema â€” emergency ultrafiltration.
description.normal:
The heart is filled with blood, removing air bubbles, and started. If it does not Â«wake upÂ» on its own, an electric shock is used. Then the rhythm is checked â€” it should be smooth! Titanium staples are inserted into the sternum and the wound is sutured.
