ðŸ“Œ An exciting moment: the correct sinus rhythm is visible on the monitor for the first time â€” it means the labyrinth is working!

description.professional:
Days 1â€“3: Mechanical ventilation (with sternotomy), ECG monitoring, TEE. Antiarrhythmics (amiodarone 1.2 g/day). Anticoagulants (heparin â†’ warfarin, target INR 2â€“3).
7 days: Holter monitoring. Assessment of sinus node function.
1 month: Stress EchoCG, discontinuation of antiarrhythmics with stable rhythm.
Complications:
- Bleeding (5â€“10%).
- Sick sinus syndrome (3â€“5%).
- Recurrent AF (10â€“15% in the first year).
Instruments:
- Holter monitor (3-channel)
- INR meter to monitor warfarin
Note: With bradycardia â€” temporary pacemaker; with persistent â€” permanent.
description.normal:
The first days â€” in intensive care: the heart Â«learnsÂ» to work with new conduction pathways. If the rhythm gets out of order, amiodarone is given. After a month, tests are done: if everything is fine, the patient forgets about the antiarrhythmia pills.
ðŸ“Œ Good news: 85% of patients after MAZE live AF-free for 10+ years!

modes.professional: A minimally invasive procedure to restore blood flow in the coronary arteries by installing a stent. Includes catheterization, angiography, balloon dilation and stenting under X-ray control. The choice of stent (BMS, DES) and anticoagulation control are critical.
modes.normal: A tube with a balloon and stent is inserted through a puncture in the arm or groin to open a blocked artery in the heart. Surgery without incisions - the patient is conscious.

description.professional:
Preparation of the surgical field (wrist artery or femoral). Local anesthesia (lidocaine 1%). Puncture of the artery with an 18G needle, insertion of an introducer 6-7F. Installation of an arterial hose for pressure monitoring. Administration of heparin (70 U/kg) to prevent thrombosis.
Instruments:
- Seldinger needle
- Introducer with cuff
- 0.035 guide catheter
Technique:
1. Puncture of the artery at an angle of 45Â°.
2. Insertion of the guide catheter to the ascending aorta.
3. Fixation of the introducer with a suture.
Logistics:
- ACT (activated clotting time) control>250 sec.
Nuance: With radial access - Allen test to check collateral blood flow.
description.normal:
The patient's arm or groin is treated, and an anesthetic injection is given. A plastic tube is inserted through a tiny puncture - this is the Â«entranceÂ» for the catheter.
ðŸ“Œ Interesting point: the patient is awake and can look at the screen, where his arteries are visible!

description.professional:
Selective coronary artery catheterization (Judkins Left/Right catheters). Contrast administration (iodine-containing, for example, Ultravist). Fluoroscopy in 4 projections: LAO, RAO, cranial, caudal. Evaluation of the degree of stenosis according to the TIMI classification.
Instruments:
- 5F angiographic catheter
- Automatic contrast injector
- C-arm with digital subtraction analysis
Technique:
1. Recording a Â«movieÂ» in DICOM format.
2. Measuring the diameter of the artery and the length of stenosis (QCA analysis).
Logistics:
- The contrast dose does not exceed 4 ml/kg.
Nuance: In case of chronic occlusion - search for the Â«tailÂ» contrast.
description.normal:
A contrast agent is injected through a catheter and an X-ray video is taken. The screen shows where the artery is narrowed or blocked.
ðŸ“Œ Important: the contrast may cause a feeling of warmth - this is normal!

description.professional:
Insertion of a 0.014" guidewire beyond the stenosis area. Installation of a balloon catheter (size 1:1 to the artery). Inflation of the balloon (pressure 8-16 atm) for 30-60 sec. Control of recanalization using contrast. In case of resistant stenosis - use of Â«cuttingÂ» balloons (Scoring/Cutting).
Instruments:
- Semi-compatible balloon (Monorail)
- Inflator with manometer
- Guidewire with hydrophilic coating
Technique:
1. Balloon positioning using marks.
2. Gradual inflation to minimize dissection.
Logistics:
- The balloon is used only after confirming the intraluminal position.
Nuance: In case of calcification â€” rotational atherectomy (Rotablator).
description.normal:
A thin balloon is inserted to the narrowing site, inflated â€” the artery expands. Sometimes a balloon with Â«bladesÂ» is used if the plaque is too hard.
ðŸ“Œ Fact of life: the balloon deflates, but the stent remains â€” like a spring in a shirt!

description.professional:
Stent selection (length +2 mm to the lesion, diameter according to the reference). DES (with medication) at high risk of restenosis. Positioning under X-ray. Inflating the stent balloon to the nominal pressure. Stent apposition control (OCT/IVUS if necessary).
Instruments:
- Stent system (e.g. Xience Alpine)
- Intracoronary ultrasound (IVUS)
- Optical coherence tomography (OCT)
Technique:
1. Â«Open cell designÂ» for side branches.
2. Postdilation with a non-compliant balloon (18-28 atm).
Logistics:
- Checking the proximal/distal edge (Â«landing zonesÂ»).
Nuance: For bifurcations - the Â«T-stentingÂ» technique.
description.normal:
A stent is a metal mesh that is opened in the artery. It remains there forever, keeping the vessel open.
ðŸ“Œ Fun fact: modern stents are coated with a drug that prevents re-narrowing.

description.professional:
Repeat angiography to assess TIMI 3 blood flow. Removal of the guidewire and introducer. Hemostasis: radial access - compression bracelet; femoral - Angio-Seal device or manual compression for 15 min. Prescription of dual antiplatelet therapy (aspirin + clopidogrel / ticagrelor).
Instruments:
- Hemostasis device (TR Band)
- Peripheral suture device (Perclose)
- Pressure sensor (if left)
Postoperative protocol:
1. ECG monitoring for 24 hours.
2. Activation after 2-6 hours.
3. Discharge in 1-2 days.
Complications:
- Restenosis (5-10% for DES).
- Stent thrombosis (<1%).
- Access site hematoma (3%).
description.normal:
After the procedure, a pressure bandage is applied to the arm or groin. The patient can get up in a few hours!
ðŸ“Œ Good news: the surgery reduces the risk of heart attack by 70%.

modes.professional: Replacement of the diseased aortic valve with an autograft from the patient's own pulmonary valve, followed by implantation of the homograft in the pulmonary position. Stages: sternotomy, connection of CPB, pulmonary valve harvesting, implantation in the aortic position, pulmonary valve replacement. Control of coronary arteries and autograft geometry is critical.
modes.normal: The surgeon replaces the diseased aortic valve with a healthy valve from the patient's own pulmonary artery, and puts a donor valve in its place. The operation is complex, but allows you to avoid lifelong medication.

description.professional:
Induction of general anesthesia: propofol (2 mg / kg), fentanyl (5 mcg / kg), rocuronium (0.6 mg / kg). Tracheal intubation, connection of mechanical ventilation. Installation of invasive monitoring (arterial line, CVP, TEE). Median sternotomy: skin incision from the jugular notch to the xiphoid process, dissection of the sternum with an oscillating saw. Hemostasis of the bone edge with wax.
Instruments:
- Oscillating saw with a protective cover
- Sternum retractor
- Bone wax
Technique:
1. Incision along the midline with preservation of the sternoclavicular ligaments.
2. Layer-by-layer dissection of tissues to the periosteum.
3. Control of bleeding from the sternal arteries.
Logistics:
- Used saw blades are immediately disposed of.
Nuance: In children under 10 years old - partial sternotomy to preserve the growth of the sternum.
description.normal:
The patient is given general anesthesia through a tube in the trachea. The surgeon cuts the sternum in the center - from the base of the neck to the solar plexus. The edges are spread with a special dilator, opening access to the heart.
ðŸ“Œ Important: after the surgery, the bone will be connected with titanium staples - they will remain forever, but do not interfere with MRI.

description.professional:
Cannulation of the aorta (cannula 20-24 Fr) and right atrium (double-lumen cannula 32-36 Fr). Connection to the artificial circulation (AC) machine. Start of perfusion. Introduction of cardioplegic solution (Custodiol 20 ml/kg) into the aortic root after clamping. Cooling the patient to 28-32Â°C.
Instruments:
- Fogarty aortic clamp
- Cannulas for CPB with turbulent flow
- Thermoregulation system with heat exchanger
Technique:
1. Proximal anastomosis of the cannula to the ascending aorta.
2. Venous drainage through the right atrium.
3. ACT control >480 sec.
Logistics:
- The perfusionist controls the flow of 2.4 l/min/mÂ².
Nuance: In case of aortic calcification - canification of the iliac arteries.
description.normal:
Tubes are inserted into the aorta and right atrium, connected to a device that temporarily replaces the heart and lungs. The heart is stopped with a special solution - now the surgeon can work on the motionless organ.
ðŸ“Œ Interesting: body temperature drops to 28Â°C - it's like hibernation to protect the brain.

description.professional:
The pulmonary trunk is incised 5 mm above the valve. Microsurgical isolation of the valve with a section of the pulmonary artery (15-20 mm cone). Preservation of the integrity of the leaflets and the fibrous ring. Orientation marking (6-0 Prolene commissural sutures). Irrigation in cold saline.
Instruments:
- McPherson micro scissors
- Freer dissector
- Irrigator with cardioplegia 4Â°C
Technique:
1. Identification of the left coronary artery to prevent damage.
2. Resection of the valve as a single block with the muscular ring.
3. Control for the absence of calcification of the leaflets.
Logistics:
- The autograft is stored in an ice solution.
Nuance: In the case of a bicuspid pulmonary valve, the decision on the modification of equipment.
description.normal:
The surgeon carefully cuts out the patient's healthy pulmonary valve together with the Â«sleeveÂ» from the artery. The valve is placed in a cold solution - like an organ for transplantation.
ðŸ“Œ Important: the valve is marked with threads to avoid confusing the top and bottom during installation.

description.professional:
Resection of the aortic valve with preservation of the coronary orifices. Preparation of the aortic ring (decalcification if necessary). Fixation of the autograft with a continuous 5-0 Prolene suture. Reimplantation of the coronary arteries into the Â«neoaortaÂ» (island inclusion technique). Leak test at 100 mmHg.
Instruments:
- Hegar calibration probes
- Castroviejo needle holder
- PTFE suture material
Technique:
1. Commissure triangulation for symmetry.
2. Formation of a Â«tongueÂ» for the coronary orifice.
3. Test for the absence of paravalvular regurgitation.
Logistics:
- Autograft ischemia time <90 min.
Nuance: In Marfan syndrome - additional strengthening of the ring.
description.normal:
The diseased aortic valve is removed, the site for the new one is cleared. The patient's pulmonary valve is sutured in its place, precisely aligning all the Â«petalsÂ». The coronary arteries, like water pipes, are reconnected to the new structure.
ðŸ“Œ The tricky part: the slightest misalignment of the valve will cause a leak - a delicate job!

description.professional:
Implantation of a cryopreserved homograft (or bioprosthesis) in the pulmonary position. Anastomosis of the pulmonary artery trunk with a continuous 5-0 PDS suture. Removal of air emboli from the heart chambers. Gradual warming of the patient. Starting the heart with defibrillation (10-20 J) if necessary.
Instruments:
- Homograft with a matching size (Â±2 mm)
- Electrocardioverter-defibrillator
- 25G deaeration needle
Technique:
1. Distal anastomosis first - for precise alignment.
2. Maintaining the length of the homograft to prevent compression.
3. Monitoring the valve function with intraoperative echocardiography.
Logistics:
- The homograft is defrosted in 3 stages over 30 minutes.
Nuance: In children, a Â«growth sutureÂ» is left along the anterior wall.
description.normal:
A donor valve or bioprosthesis is installed in place of the removed pulmonary valve. Everything is carefully stitched and checked for leaks. The heart is filled with blood, removing air bubbles - like when bleeding the brakes in a car.
ðŸ“Œ A miracle: when the heart is started, the new valve immediately starts working!

description.professional:
Decannulation after stabilization of hemodynamics. Installation of drains (mediastinal and pleural). Suturing the sternum with wire (8-10 threads). Layer-by-layer closure of the wound. Connection to a temporary pacemaker for AV block. Transesophageal echocardiography control.
Instruments:
- Blake 19Fr drain
- 5 mm steel wire for the sternum
- Implantable pacemaker electrode
Postoperative protocol:
1. Inotropic support (epinephrine 0.02-0.1 mcg/kg/min).
2. Anticoagulation (heparin 300 U/kg/day).
3. CT scan after 48 hours to evaluate the homograft.
Complications:
- Bleeding (5%).
- Blockade of the conduction pathways (3%).
- Autograft regurgitation (1% per year).
description.normal:
The tubes from the CPB are removed, the heart starts working on its own again. Drains for fluid are placed in the chest. The sternum is fastened with titanium wire - like a plumbing clamp. In 5-7 days, the patient can breathe without pain!
ðŸ“Œ The main thing: this valve will grow with the child and does not require replacement.

keys: removal of a lobe of the lung
name: Lung lobectomy

modes.professional: Radical removal of a lobe of the lung in case of malignant or benign lesions. Stages: thoracotomy / VATS access, isolation of the lobe, treatment of vessels and bronchus, lymph node dissection, drainage. Control of the pulmonary arteries and anastomoses is critical.
modes.normal: Surgery to remove one lobe of the lung, most often in case of cancer. The surgeon removes the affected area, preserving the healthy parts of the lung.

description.professional:
Dual-lumen intubation for separate lung ventilation. Position on the healthy side with a cushion under the chest. Monitoring: invasive BP, TEE, SpO2. Prophylactic antibiotic therapy (cefazolin 2 g IV).
Instruments:
- Double-lumen tube 37-39 Fr
- Bronchoscope for position control
- Neuromonitoring sensors
Technique:
1. Checking the lung isolation with an apnea test.
2. Fiberoptic repositioning of the tube in case of collapse.
Logistics:
- Marking the blood pressure level on the dependent arm.
Nuance: With VATS - the Â«swimmerÂ» position with arm abduction.
description.normal:
The patient is placed on his side, a special tube is inserted into the trachea so that one lung can be disconnected during surgery. This gives the surgeon space to work.
ðŸ“Œ Important: before the surgery, it is imperative to check how the patient tolerates the disconnection of one lung - a breathing test is done.

description.professional:
Anterolateral thoracotomy along the 5th intercostal space (length 10-15 cm) or VATS (3 ports + utility incision). Dissection of the muscles: latissimus dorsi, anterior serratus, intercostal. Introduction of a retractor with gradual opening. Revision of the pleural cavity.
Instruments:
- Finochetto rib retractor
- Thoracoscope 10 mm 30Â°
- Harmonic scalpel
Technique:
1. In VATS - the camera is in the 7th intercostal space along the midaxillary line.
2. Protection of the intercostal nerve by blunt dissection.
Logistics:
- Hemostasis with an electrocoagulator in the Â«sprayÂ» mode.
Nuance: For tumors >5 cm - conversion to open surgery.
description.normal:
The surgeon makes an incision between the ribs (or several small punctures in VATS). The muscles are carefully moved apart, the ribs are slightly spread apart with a special instrument - like opening curtains.
ðŸ“Œ Interesting: with VATS access, the operation is performed through 3-4 holes, looking at the monitor screen - like in a computer game, but for real!

description.professional:
Division of the interlobar fissure: blunt dissection along the avascular plane, treatment of vascular adhesions with bipolar. Identification of the elements of the root of the lobe: artery, vein, bronchus. Sequential processing: first arterial branches, then venous, finally - bronchus.
Instruments:
- Maryland dissector
- Stapling device (Echelon 60)
- Hem-o-lok clips
Technique:
1. In case of upper lobectomy on the right - isolation of truncus anterior.
2. Mobilization of the azygos vein if necessary.
Logistics:
- Marking the direction of resection using CT navigation.
Nuance: In case of inflammation - intrapericardial processing of vessels.
description.normal:
The surgeon finds the border between the lobes of the lung - like separating the layers of a cake. The vessels and bronchus feeding the affected lobe are carefully isolated.
ðŸ“Œ A difficult moment: the pulmonary arteries are very thin - like spaghetti, they are easy to damage, so they work with jewelry precision.

description.professional:
Ligation and intersection of pulmonary arteries (Prolene 4-0 suture material or staplers). Ligation of pulmonary veins (Echelon stapler or clips). Intersection of the lobar bronchus 5 mm distal to the carina (Endo GIA 3.5 mm stapler). Checking the tightness of the bronchial stump with a test with saline.
Instruments:
- Bronchial stapler with a blue cassette
- Vascular stapler (white cassette)
- Irrigator with warm saline
Technique:
1. Arteries are treated proximal to the veins.
2. The bronchus is crossed at a 45Â° angle to maintain its shape.
Logistics:
- The removed vessels are checked for the presence of two rows of staples.
Note: If the bronchus is short - hand suture PDS 3-0.
description.normal:
Each vessel is clamped with a stapler - like a paper clip, then crossed. The bronchus (air Â«tubeÂ») is also blocked and cut off, checking that there is no air leakage.
ðŸ“Œ Important: if the bronchus is too short, the surgeon sutures it manually - this requires special skill.

description.professional:
Removal of lymph nodes of stations 7, 10, 11 (for NSCLC). Isolation of packets from the bifurcation of the trachea to the phrenic nerve. Marking of groups of lymph nodes separately for histology. Hemostasis of lymphatic vessels with clips.
Instruments:
- LigaSure bipolar forceps
- Metzenbaum scissors
- Lymph node containers
Technique:
1. Complete mediastinal dissection for cancer.
2. Preservation of the recurrent laryngeal nerve.
Logistics:
- Separate marking of Â«subcranialÂ» nodes.
Note: At stage N2 - intraoperative consultation with an oncologist.
description.normal:
The surgeon removes all the lymph nodes around the lung - this is where cancer spreads first. They are marked and sent for urgent analysis.
ðŸ“Œ Critical: if tumor cells are found in the nodes, an extension of the operation may be required.

description.professional:
Revision of the bed for hemostasis (especially the intercostal arteries). Installation of two drains: anterior - to the dome, posterior - to the diaphragm. Layered suturing: intercostal muscles (Vicryl 2-0), subcutaneous tissue, skin (stapler or subcuticular suture). Connecting the drains to the active aspiration system (-20 cm H2O).
Instruments:
- Pleurovac 28 Fr drain
- Absorbable mesh (for rib resection)
- Hegar needle holder
Postoperative protocol:
1. X-ray immediately after surgery.
2. Analgesia: epidural catheter + Paracetamol.
3. Activation after 4-6 hours.
Complications:
- Bronchial fistula (1-2%).
- Bleeding (3%).
- Atelectasis (15%).
description.normal:
The lung is carefully straightened, checking for air leaks. Two drainage tubes are inserted into the chest - they will remove air and fluid. The ribs are brought back together, the muscles and skin are stitched up. After 1-2 days, the drains are removed, and after a week the patient can breathe almost normally!
ðŸ“Œ Good news: the remaining lobes of the lung will expand over time and take over the work of the removed part.

modes.professional: Radical removal of the entire lung with the main bronchus, pulmonary vessels and lymph node dissection. Indications: central cancer with damage to the main bronchus, tumors with invasion of the pulmonary veins/arteries. Critical stages: treatment of the main pulmonary artery, sealing of the bronchial stump, control of the mediastinum.
modes.normal: Complete removal of one lung in advanced tumors or severe injuries. After the operation, the remaining lung gradually takes over the entire respiratory function.

description.professional:
Double-lumen intubation with bronchoscope position control. Position on the healthy side with a cushion under the chest. Monitoring: invasive BP, CVP, BIS, gas analysis. Posterolateral thoracotomy along the 5th intercostal space with resection of the 5th rib (length 15-20 cm). Insertion of a rib spreader.
Instruments:
- Double-lumen tube 39-41 Fr
- Liston rib scissors
- Finochetto retractor
Technique:
1. Rib resection 2 cm lateral to the paravertebral line.
2. Drainage of pleural fluid before deployment.
Logistics:
- Extracorporeal membrane oxygenation (ECMO) readiness.
Nuance: For tumors >10 cm, transsternal access is possible.
description.normal:
The patient is placed on his side, a special breathing tube is inserted to work with only one lung. The surgeon makes a large incision along the ribs, sometimes removing one rib for better access.
ðŸ“Œ Important: before the operation, it is imperative to check how the remaining lung copes with breathing - special tests are done.

description.professional:
Dissection of the pulmonary ligament. Isolation of the main bronchus to the tracheal bifurcation. Separation of the lung from the mediastinum with ligation of small vessels. Treatment of the pulmonary artery: isolation extrapericardial or intrapericardial (for central tumors).
Instruments:
- Debakey dissector
- LigaSure bipolar forceps
- Satinsky vascular clamps
Technique:
1. For right-sided pulmonectomy - mobilization of the azygos vein.
2. Control of the left recurrent nerve for left-sided.
Logistics:
- Marking the tumor borders with surgical clips.
Nuance: In case of growth into the pericardium - resection of the pericardial window.
description.normal:
The surgeon carefully separates the lung from all attachments, like freeing the root of a tree from the ground. The main vessels and the bronchus are isolated especially carefully - they are large, like a garden hose.
ðŸ“Œ A difficult moment: the nerve responsible for the voice runs nearby - it must be preserved at any cost!

description.professional:
Ligation and transection of the main pulmonary artery: double ligature proximally (silk 0) + distal stapler (Echelon 60 mm). Alternatively, hand suture with 4-0 Prolene. Intrapericardial approach - pericardial opening anterior to the phrenic nerve.
Instruments:
- Vascular stapler with white cassette
- Castroviejo needle holder
- Pericardial scissors
Technique:
1. Proximal control of the artery before mobilization.
2. Suture strength test by increasing pressure.
Logistics:
- Readiness of 5-0 vascular suture material.
Nuance: In case of arterial calcification - use of Teflon pads.
description.normal:
The pulmonary artery, the main Â«pipeÂ» that carries blood to the lung, is clamped and cut. First, strong knots are applied, then it is cut.
ðŸ“Œ Critical: if the artery is damaged, severe bleeding can begin, so the surgeon always keeps spare sutures on hand.

description.professional:
Isolation of the superior and inferior pulmonary veins extrapericardially or together with the atrial appendage (in case of tumor invasion). Application of a Satinsky clamp to the atrium. Dissection of the veins with 3-0 Prolene suturing in a double-row suture. Control of the tightness of the suture with an adrenaline swab.
Instruments:
- Satinsky clamp 45 mm
- Polypropylene thread 3-0
- ValleyLab electrocoagulator
Technique:
1. In case of invasion into the atrium - resection using a vascular stapler.
2. Mandatory check for blood clots in the appendage.
Logistics:
- Hemostasis with bipolar in 25 W mode.
Nuance: With left-sided surgery - risk air embolism through an open ear.
description.normal:
The pulmonary veins that return blood to the heart are carefully cut and stitched up. Sometimes part of the heart wall has to be removed - like stitching up a hole in an air mattress.
ðŸ“Œ Important: before cutting, check for blood clots - they can get into the heart.

description.professional:
Mobilization of the bronchus to the carina. Application of a bronchial stapler (blue cassette) 5 mm distal to the bifurcation. Intersection of the bronchus with a #11 scalpel. Sealing the stump with 3-0 Prolene (braided suture). Pleuralization with a mediastinal pleural or pericardial flap.
Instruments:
- Bronchial stapler TA 30
- Schumacher needle
- Pleural flap on a pedicle
Technique:
1. Control of the stump length (no more than 1 cm).
2. Tightness test under water at a pressure of 30 cm H2O.
Logistics:
- Sanitation of the stump with a povidone-iodine solution.
Nuance: With a right-sided operation - risk bend of the left main bronchus.
description.normal:
The main bronchus - the Â«breathing tubeÂ» - is compressed with a special stapler, cut off and carefully sutured. The suture site is covered with a Â«patchÂ» from the surrounding tissue.
ðŸ“Œ Vital: if the suture is not airtight, air will escape into the chest cavity - like a punctured chamber.

description.professional:
Extended lymph node dissection: paratracheal, bifurcation, subcarinal nodes (stations 2R, 4R, 7, 8, 9). Mediastinal hemostasis with argon-enhanced coagulation. Installation of two drains: anterior - to the pleural dome, posterior - to the diaphragm. Layered suturing with thoracoplasty (resection ribs are reimplanted with titanium plates).
Instruments:
- Titanium lymphatic clips
- ForceTriad argon coagulator
- MatrixRIB rib plates
Postoperative protocol:
1. Mechanical ventilation in PCV mode for the first 12-24 hours.
2. Epidural analgesia for 5 days.
3. Bronchoscopy on the 3rd day.
Complications:
- Bronchial fistula (3-5%).
- Pleural empyema (7%).
- Postpneumonectomy space syndrome (10%).
description.normal:
The surgeon removes all the lymph nodes in the mediastinum - like uprooting the roots of a weed. The chest is closed, sometimes reinforced with titanium plates. Two drainage tubes are left for monitoring.
ðŸ“Œ Rehabilitation: the first few days the patient breathes through a ventilator, but after a week the remaining lung begins to work for two!

modes.professional: An invasive procedure for inserting a drainage tube into the pleural cavity to remove air (pneumothorax), blood (hemothorax), or exudate (pleurisy). Includes local anesthesia, puncture, insertion of a Bulau drain, or connection to an aspiration system.
modes.normal: When air or fluid accumulates in the chest, interfering with breathing, the doctor inserts a special tube between the ribs. All excess is removed through it, and the lung straightens out again.

description.professional:
Choosing the access point: for pneumothorax - 4-5 intercostal space along the midclavicular line, for effusion - 7-8 intercostal space along the posterior axillary line. Patient position: sitting with a forward bend (for effusion) or lying on the healthy side (for injury). Treating the field with an antiseptic in wide strokes (from the sternum to the spine). Marking the injection site according to ultrasound/X-ray data.
Instruments:
- Ultrasound machine with a linear sensor
- Skin marker
- Sterile tray with napkins
Technique:
1. Palpation of the ribs to identify the intercostal space.
2. Ultrasound control of the depth of effusion/air.
3. Full-thickness infiltration of anesthetic walls.
Logistics:
- Check the function of the aspirator before starting.
Nuance: In case of tension pneumothorax - immediate puncture with a 14G needle in the 2nd intercostal space.
description.normal:
The patient is seated on the bed so that he hugs the pillow and leans slightly forward - this way the ribs move apart. The doctor finds the desired intercostal space (usually between the 4-5 rib under the arm) and treats the skin with a cold antiseptic.
ðŸ“Œ Important: before the injection, an ultrasound is done - like an Â«underwater locatorÂ» it looks for fluid accumulation.

description.professional:
Layered infiltration anesthesia: skin (1% lidocaine 3-5 ml), subcutaneous tissue, intercostal muscles, parietal pleura. A 22G needle 40 mm long is inserted along the upper edge of the rib (avoiding the vascular-nerve bundle). Aspiration test when advancing - air/liquid appears when entering the cavity.
Instruments:
- 10 ml syringe with a 22G needle
- 1% lidocaine or 0.5% bupivacaine
- Test tube for effusion analysis
Technique:
1. Anesthesia is started from the skin to the pleura.
2. Â«FanÂ» technique - 3 intercostal spaces are blocked.
3. Depth control by tissue resistance.
Logistics:
- Any remaining anesthetic is disposed of in a Â«sharpÂ» container.
Note: For children, the dose is calculated as 3 mg/kg lidocaine.
description.normal:
Several injections of anesthetic are given - first superficially, then deeper, right down to the pleura. The doctor may ask you to hold your breath so as not to accidentally injure the lung.
ðŸ“Œ Interesting: an area the size of a palm is anesthetized - then the installation of the tube will be painless.

description.professional:
A 1.5-2 cm transverse skin incision with a #11 scalpel. Blunt separation of the subcutaneous tissue with a mosquito clamp. Puncture of the intercostal muscles with a trocar or Pean clamp along the upper edge of the rib. Digital revision: a finger is inserted into the wound to confirm the position in the pleural cavity and separate the adhesions.
Instruments:
- Scalpel #11 with a depth limiter
- Blunt Kelly clamp
- Trocar 28-32Fr (for planned drainage)
Technique:
1. The incision is strictly perpendicular to the skin.
2. Â«TunnelingÂ» through the muscles at an angle of 45Â°.
3. Digital control before inserting the drainage.
Logistics:
- The used trocar is immediately washed.
Nuance: In case of adhesions, the access is expanded to 3 cm.
description.normal:
The surgeon makes a small incision (like for an earring), then carefully spreads the muscles between the ribs with a blunt instrument. An important point is that he inserts his finger into the incision to make sure that he has entered the pleural cavity exactly.
ðŸ“Œ Sensation: the patient may feel pressure, but not pain.

description.professional:
Insertion of a 24-32Fr drainage tube (for blood - 36Fr) 10-15 cm into the pleural cavity. When using a trocar, remove the stylet after positioning. Fixation of the tube to the skin with a 1-0 silk suture. Connection to the Bulau system (underwater valve) or an electric aspirator (-20 cm H2O). Application of an occlusive dressing.
Instruments:
- Chest drain with side holes
- Suture set with needle holder
- System with Heimlich valve
Technique:
1. Direction of the tube in case of pneumothorax - to the apex of the lung.
2. In case of effusion â€” to the posterior costophrenic angle.
3. X-ray position control after installation.
Logistics:
- The drainage is fixed with a â€œsafetyâ€ suture.
Nuance: In children â€” soft drains 12-16Fr are used.
description.normal:
A flexible tube (as thick as a finger) is inserted through the incision and advanced inside. In case of pneumothorax â€” to the top of the lung, in case of fluid â€” down, like a â€œhoseâ€ to the deepest point. The tube is sewn to the skin with a thread so that it does not fall out, and connected to a jar of water or a suction device.
ðŸ“Œ Visualization: air bubbles or a stream of liquid are visible in the jar â€” this means the drainage is working!

description.professional:
X-ray/ultrasound immediately after the procedure. Monitoring the volume of discharge (dangerous >1500 ml/day). Flushing the drainage with 0.9% NaCl if blocked. Daily treatment of the insertion site. Auscultation of the lungs for straightening.
Instruments:
- X-ray machine (portable)
- Sterile wipes with chlorhexidine
- 20 ml syringe for flushing
Technique:
1. Marking the fluid level on the drainage jar.
2. Checking the water fluctuation in the system.
3. Clamping the drainage during transportation.
Logistics:
- Change the aseptic dressing every 24 hours.
Note: With long-term drainage - prevention of empyema (ceftriaxone 1 g/day).
description.normal:
After the procedure, an X-ray is taken to check whether the lung has straightened. Nurses measure the volume of outflowing fluid daily and flush the tube with saline if it becomes clogged.
ðŸ“Œ Important: Always keep the drainage can below chest level - otherwise the fluid may Â«leakÂ» back!

description.professional:
Indications: cessation of air/fluid inflow (>24 h), lung straightening on x-ray, discharge volume <100 ml/day. Preparation: pain relief, premedication (morphine 2-4 mg IV). Rapid removal of the tube on exhalation with simultaneous application of an occlusive dressing. Control x-ray after 2 hours.
Instruments:
- Suture scissors
- Vaseline wipes
- Steri-Strips patch
Technique:
1. Changing the drainage ligation within 2 hours to assess for recurrence.
2. Â«JerkyÂ» removal in one go.
3. Sealing the wound with an ointment dressing.
Postoperative protocol:
1. Pain relief (paracetamol + ketorolac).
2. Breathing exercises from the first day.
3. Discharge 24-48 hours after removal.
Complications:
- Subcutaneous emphysema (15%).
- Recurrence of pneumothorax (5%).
- Infection (3%).
description.normal:
When the lung has recovered, the tube is removed: the doctor asks you to take a deep breath and hold it, and then quickly removes the drainage. A tight bandage is applied to the wound - like a Â«patchÂ» on a punctured ball.
ðŸ“Œ Advice: after removal, it is better to lie on this side for 2 hours - this way the wound will close more reliably.

modes.professional: Surgical interruption of the sympathetic trunk at the level of the thoracic ganglia for the treatment of hyperhidrosis, Raynaud's syndrome or phantom pain. Performed videoendoscopically through mini-accesses with clipping, resection or ablation of nerve nodes.
modes.normal: Surgery against excessive sweating of the hands or face - through small punctures in the armpits, the doctor Â«disconnectsÂ» the nerve nodes responsible for the sweat glands. The result is dry palms on the day of surgery.

description.professional:
General anesthesia with double-lumen intubation (lung isolation). Patient position on the back with arms spread at 90Â°. Marking of access points: 3rd intercostal space along the midaxillary line (5 mm for the camera) and 5th intercostal space along the anterior axillary line (3 mm for instruments). Treatment of the field with an antiseptic.
Instruments:
- Double-lumen endotracheal tube
- Thoracoscope 5 mm 30Â°
- Needles for COâ‚‚ insufflation
Technique:
1. Collapse of the lung on the side to be operated on.
2. Control X-ray to identify the rib level.
3. Hyperhidrosis test (iodine-starch test).
Logistics:
- Mark of the surgeon's dominant hand (right-handed/left-handed).
Nuance: In case of obesity â€” increase insufflation pressure to 8 mmHg.
description.normal:
The patient is placed on his back, arms spread out like a Â«crossÂ». Anesthesia is administered through a special tube â€” one lung is temporarily disconnected for work. The skin in the armpits is treated with iodine and Â«targetsÂ» for punctures are drawn.
ðŸ“Œ Important: before the operation, the palms are lubricated with iodine and starch â€” sweaty areas turn purple so that the surgeon knows exactly which nerves to block.

description.professional:
The pleural cavity in the 4th intercostal space is punctured with a Veresh needle. COâ‚‚ insufflation (pressure 4-6 mmHg) for lung collapse. Insertion of a 5 mm trocar under visual control. Examination of the pleural cavity: identification of the sympathetic trunk (a cord with ganglia along the heads of the ribs).
Instruments:
- Veress needle with a protective valve
- Insufflator with gas heating
- Thoracotrocar with obturator
Technique:
1. Puncture strictly along the upper edge of the rib.
2. Control of the depth by the Â«failureÂ» of resistance.
3. Visualization of the sympathetic chain â€” a pearly white structure.
Logistics:
- EtCOâ‚‚ monitoring (not >45 mmHg).
Nuance: In case of adhesions â€” an additional 3rd port.
description.normal:
Carbon dioxide is injected through a tiny puncture â€” it gently pushes the lung back, freeing up space for work. The surgeon inserts a camera and sees the nerve chain â€” it looks like a white cord running along the spine.
ðŸ“Œ Amazing: the entire operation takes place through holes less than a centimeter â€” like a game of Tetris inside the chest!

description.professional:
Visualization of ganglia: T2 (for palms), T3-T4 (for face), T5 (for armpits). Separation of the chain from the intercostal veins (often anastomosed with the azygos vein). Coagulation of transverse communicants. Test stimulation with an electrosurgical hook (if there is doubt about identification).
Instruments:
- Maryland electrosurgical hook
- Bipolar forceps
- Atraumatic dissector
Technique:
1. Dissection along the axis of the trunk without damaging the pleura.
2. Control of bleeding from the venous plexuses.
3. Marking the target ganglia with a clip.
Logistics:
- Recording of video surgery for documentation.
Nuance: In case of atypical anatomy, search in relation to the costal heads.
description.normal:
The surgeon finds the necessary Â«nodesÂ» of the nerve chain - for the palms, this is the level of the second rib, for the face, the third. Nerves are carefully separated from small vessels - like wires are stripped of insulation. Sometimes they are tested with electricity - if the palm of your hand sweats on the monitor, it means that this is the right node.
ðŸ“Œ Subtlety: one wrong step - and you can touch important veins going to the heart!

description.professional:
Intervention options:
1. Clipping with titanium clips (reversible in case of complications).
2. Radiofrequency ablation (50-70 Â° C, 30 sec).
3. Resection of the trunk segment (histological control).
Mandatory T3-T4 sympathectomy for palmar hyperhidrosis. Hemostasis control. Checking pupil dilation (Horner's syndrome with T1 damage).
Instruments:
- Clip applicator with 5 mm titanium clips
- RF generator with a needle electrode
- Endoscopic scissors
Technique:
1. Clips are applied to the trunk + 1 cm distally.
2. For ablation - circular treatment of a 5 mm zone.
3. The removed fragment is sent for histology.
Logistics:
- The number of clips is recorded in the protocol.
Nuance: In case of Raynaud's syndrome â€” additional T2 sympathectomy.
description.normal:
The chosen method of Â«disablingÂ» the nerves:
â€¢ The gold standard is titanium clips (like microscopic clothespins).
â€¢ Or Â«cauterizationÂ» with a radiofrequency beam.
â€¢ In rare cases, a section of the nerve is cut out.
ðŸ“Œ The result is visible immediately: your palms become dry and warm right on the operating table!

description.professional:
Lung reinflation under visual control. Removal of trocars under video observation. Suturing of ports with absorbable suture 3-0. Drainage is not required. Application of aseptic stickers. Extubation in the operating room.
Instruments:
- Monocryl suture material
- Skin stapler
- Pneumatic system for reinflation
Technique:
1. Control of complete lung expansion.
2. Aspiration of residual gas through the port.
3. Cosmetic intradermal suture.
Logistics:
- Checking the pupils for symmetry.
Nuance: In case of subcutaneous emphysema - X-ray control.
description.normal:
The lung is filled with air again, like a balloon. The punctures are sealed with a special plaster - no stitches are needed, the marks are almost invisible. In 30 minutes the patient is already in the ward and can eat.
ðŸ“Œ Fact: 95% of people say goodbye to sweaty palms forever!

description.professional:
X-ray after 2 hours to exclude pneumothorax. Assessment of compensatory hyperhidrosis (back, abdomen). Cold palm test. Discharge after 24 hours. Limitation of physical activity for 7 days.
Postoperative protocol:
1. Pain relief - ketorolac 30 mg / day.
2. Breathing exercises from the 1st day.
3. Follow-up examination after 1 month.
Complications:
- Compensatory hyperhidrosis (50%).
- Horner's syndrome (1-3%).
- Pneumothorax (2%).
- Neuralgia (5%).
description.normal:
After the operation, an X-ray is taken to check for air in the chest. The puncture site may hurt for the first few days, but this can be relieved with regular pills.
ðŸ“Œ Important to know: 50% of patients experience increased sweating of the back or thighs - this is the price to pay for dry palms.

modes.professional: Surgical treatment of spontaneous pneumothorax, including drainage of the pleural cavity, resection of bullae and pleurodesis. Stages: VATS access, lung revision, treatment of pathological areas, drainage. Control of air leakage and prevention of relapse are critical.
modes.normal: Surgery for sudden accumulation of air in the chest cavity. The surgeon removes the bubbles in the lung and creates conditions for the lung to stick to the chest wall, preventing recurrence.

description.professional:
Chest X-ray or CT to confirm the diagnosis and assess the volume of the pneumothorax. Puncture of the thoracostomy cavity in case of tension pneumothorax. Operating room preparation: videothoracoscopic set, tissue suturing machine, drainage systems. Single- or double-lumen intubation depending on the method.
Instruments:
- 5 mm 30Â° thoracoscope
- 5 and 10 mm trocars
- 14G puncture needle
Technique:
1. In case of tension pneumothorax - immediate decompression in the 2nd intercostal space.
2. Port markings for VATS: safety triangle.
Logistics:
- Emergency thoracotomy kit at the ready.
Note: For smokers - preparation for possible resection.
description.normal:
The patient is given an urgent X-ray to see how much air has accumulated around the lung. In severe cases, the air is first pumped out with a thick needle - it's like deflating a tire.
ðŸ“Œ Important: smokers are at risk - their lungs are often covered with weak bubbles (bullae).

description.professional:
Installation of a Bulau drainage: a 2 cm skin incision in the 4-5 intercostal space along the midaxillary line. Blunt isolation to the pleura. Insertion of a 20-28 Fr drainage tube towards the apex. Fixation with a suture and connection to the active aspiration system (-20 cm H2O).
Instruments:
- Argyle 24 Fr drainage
- Pean clamp
- Silk 2-0 suture material
Technique:
1. Digital revision of the pleural cavity before inserting the drainage.
2. Control of the drainage position with an X-ray.
Logistics:
- Sterile Heimlich valve in the system.
Nuance: With subcutaneous emphysema - additional drainage.
description.normal:
A flexible tube is inserted through a small incision under the armpit, which is connected to a jar of water. Air bubbles in the jar indicate that the system is working.
ðŸ“Œ A visual moment: when the lung straightens out, the bubbles in the drainage stop - like in an aquarium filter.

description.professional:
Position on the healthy side with arm abduction. Creation of 3 ports: camera - 7th intercostal space along the midaxillary line, instrumental - 3rd and 5th intercostal spaces along the anterior axillary line. CO2 insufflation (8 mm Hg) to improve visibility. 360Â° lung inspection.
Instruments:
- 10 mm thoracoport
- HD telescopic camera
- Insufflator with gas heating
Technique:
1. The first trocar is inserted using the Â«openÂ» method.
2. Inspection of the apex of the lung first.
Logistics:
- Position of the operating team: surgeon in front, assistant in the back.
Nuance: In case of adhesions - an additional 4th port.
description.normal:
Through three punctures (as for laparoscopy) a camera and instruments are inserted. A little gas is pumped into the chest cavity - this moves the tissues apart, giving the surgeon an overview.
ðŸ“Œ Interesting: transparent bubbles on the lung are clearly visible on the monitor - like bunches of grapes.

steps.name: Resection of bullae and lung treatment

description.professional:
Identification of bullae (usually the upper lobe). Clipping the base of the bulla with vascular clips. Resection with a mechanical stapler (Endo GIA 45 mm, blue cassette). Irrigation of the bed with saline to check for leaks. Coagulation of small bullae with an argon coagulator.
Instruments:
- Endostapler with triplex staples
- 5 mm clip applicator
- Argon-reinforced coagulator
Technique:
1. Resection with 5 mm of healthy tissue capture.
2. Leak test at 30 cm H2O pressure.
Logistics:
- The removed bullae are sent for histology.
Nuance: For giant bullae - the Â«kapitoshkaÂ» technique.
description.normal:
The surgeon finds the bubbles and cuts them off with a special stapler, which immediately stitches the tissue. The cut site is checked by pouring saline solution - if there are bubbles, then there is an air leak.
ðŸ“Œ Important: the stapler places three rows of titanium staples - like in an office stapler, but for human tissue.

description.professional:
Mechanical treatment of the parietal pleura: with a windlass or electrocoagulation until capillary bleeding occurs. Application of talc suspension (4 g of sterile talc) through a sprayer. Control of uniform distribution over the entire surface.
Instruments:
- Pleural brush
- Talc insufflator
- Electrosurgical generator
Technique:
1. Treatment from the dome to the diaphragm.
2. Talc is sprayed under visual control.
Logistics:
- Aspiration of excess talc after 5 min exposure.
Nuance: In case of talc allergy - chemical pleurodesis with doxycycline.
description.normal:
To make the lung Â«stickÂ» to the chest wall, the surgeon treats the inner surface of the chest with a special mesh or sprays sterile talc - like powder.
ðŸ“Œ Surprisingly: talc causes controlled inflammation, which creates strong adhesions.

description.professional:
Lung reimplantation under video camera control. Installation of a second 20 Fr drainage along the posterior axillary line. Removal of trocars under visual control. Layered suturing of ports. Fixation of drains with separate sutures. Connection to the Pleurovac system.
Instruments:
- Blake 20 Fr drainage
- Absorbable suture material
- Atraumatic needle
Postoperative protocol:
1. X-ray control after 2 hours.
2. Analgesia: NSAIDs + local blockades.
3. Removal of drains if there is no leak for >24 hours.
Complications:
- Persistent leak (5%).
- Pleural empyema (1%).
- Relapse (3% after VATS).
description.normal:
The drainage tubes are fixed with sutures, the punctures are sealed. A control X-ray is taken after 24 hours - if the lung has straightened and there is no air leak, the tubes are removed.
ðŸ“Œ Good news: after VATS, patients go home on the 3-4th day and quickly return to active life!

modes.professional: Minimally invasive endoscopic intervention in the pleural cavity through 3-4 ports. Indications: pleural biopsy, resection of pulmonary nodes, treatment of pneumothorax, sympathectomy. Control of bleeding and adequate ventilation of one lung are critical.
modes.normal: Surgery through small punctures in the chest with a video camera. Used to diagnose and treat lung and pleural diseases without large incisions.

description.professional:
Double-lumen intubation (37-39 Fr) for separate lung ventilation. Position on the healthy side with a cushion under the chest (in case of pneumothorax - on the back). Monitoring: capnography, SpO2, invasive BP. Lung isolation test (collapse of the operated lung).
Instruments:
- Bronchoscope for intubation control
- Double-lumen endotracheal tube
- Neuromonitoring sensors
Technique:
1. Checking the tube position with a fiberscope
2. Collapsed lung on the side of the operation
Logistics:
- Readiness for emergency thoracotomy
Nuance: With adhesions - gradual collapse of the lung
description.normal:
The patient is placed on his side, a special tube is inserted into the trachea so that one lung can be disconnected. This gives the surgeon space to work.
ðŸ“Œ Important: before the operation, check how the patient tolerates the disconnection of one lung - do a breathing test.

description.professional:
Formation of 3-4 ports (5-12 mm): a chamber in the 7th intercostal space along the midaxillary line, instrument ports in the 4th and 5th intercostal spaces. A pneumothorax is created with a Veresh needle (CO2 pressure 8-10 mm Hg). Trocars are inserted under visual control.
Instruments:
- Trocars 5/10/12 mm
- Veresh needle
- CO2 insufflator
Technique:
1. The first port is a safe zone (safety triangle)
2. Trocar insertion control with a torcoscope
Logistics:
- Ports are fixed to the skin with sutures
Nuance: In case of adhesions - open technique according to Hasson
description.normal:
The surgeon makes 3-4 small incisions (5-12 mm) between the ribs. A camera and instruments are inserted through them. Carbon dioxide is pumped into the chest to create space for work.
ðŸ“Œ Interesting: the first puncture is made in the Â«safe triangleÂ» - an area where there are no large vessels.

description.professional:
Systematic examination: costal pleura, diaphragm, mediastinum, visceral pleura. Detection of adhesions, tumor nodes, pathological fluid. Collection of effusion for cytology/microbiology. Separation of adhesions with a harmonic scalpel.
Instruments:
- Thoracoscope 30Â° 10 mm
- Harmonic scalpel
- Aspirator-irrigator
Technique:
1. Methodical examination by quadrants
2. Biopsy of suspicious areas
Logistics:
- Marking of biopsy specimens by localization
Nuance: In case of hemothorax - search for the source of bleeding
description.normal:
The surgeon examines the entire chest cavity through the camera - the lungs, diaphragm, costal surface. If there are adhesions (scar bridges), they are carefully separated. Fluid or pieces of tissue are taken for analysis.
ðŸ“Œ Important: in case of cancer, it is immediately determined whether the tumor can be removed in a minimally invasive way.

steps.name: The main stage (depending on the pathology)

description.professional:
1. For pleural biopsy: taking 3-4 samples from different areas with endoscopic forceps. 2. For bullectomy: resection of bullae with Endo GIA stapler (blue cassette). 3. For sympathectomy: coagulation of the sympathetic trunk at the R3-R4 level. 4. For tumors: marking the node with a radioisotope for further resection.
Instruments:
- Endoscopic forceps
- Stapling apparatus
- Electrocoagulator
Technique:
1. For bullae - resection with capture of healthy tissue
2. In case of biopsy - taking a full sample
Logistics:
- Hemostasis control after each stage
Nuance: In case of bleeding - switch to manual suture
description.normal:
Depending on the problem: remove blisters on the lung (bullae) in case of pneumothorax, cut nerves in case of hyperhidrosis (heavy sweating), take pieces of the tumor for analysis.
ðŸ“Œ Technical point: all incisions and sutures are made with special suturing devices - like a mini-stapler.

description.professional:
Revision for hemostasis (especially intercostal vessels). Installation of 24-28 Fr drainage through the lower port under visual control. Connection to the active aspiration system (-20 cm H2O). Layer-by-layer suturing of ports. Control X-ray in the operating room.
Instruments:
- Pleurovac chest drain
- Vicryl suture material
- C-arm X-ray machine
Technique:
1. Fixing the drain with a double suture
2. Checking the straightening of the lung
Logistics:
- The drain is removed when the discharge is <100 ml/day
Nuance: In case of prolonged exudation - connection of the Heimlich system
description.normal:
After all manipulations, a drainage tube is inserted into the chest through one of the punctures. It is connected to a jar of water to allow air and liquid to come out. The incisions are sutured with a cosmetic suture.
ðŸ“Œ Good news: the drainage is usually removed after 1-2 days, and the stitches are almost invisible.

description.professional:
Activation after 4-6 hours. Pain relief: NSAIDs + local block. Breathing exercises from the first day. Control X-ray after 24 hours. Removal of drainage in the absence of air/blood. Discharge on the 3-5th day.
Instruments:
- Spirometer for exercise therapy
- Portable X-ray machine
- Thoracic belt
Postoperative protocol:
1. Antibiotics 24 hours
2. Analgesics according to the scheme
3. Physiotherapy
Complications:
- Subcutaneous emphysema (8%)
- Persistent fistula (1%)
- Atelectasis (5%)
description.normal:
In just a few hours, the patient can get up and walk. Breathing exercises with a special device are mandatory.
ðŸ“Œ Rehabilitation: in a week you can return to normal life, and in a month - even play sports!

modes.professional: Microsurgical removal of mediastinal neoplasm with preservation of the capsule. Indications: benign thymomas, neuromas, teratomas. Stages: access to the mediastinum, isolation of the tumor from critical structures (main vessels, trachea, nerves), hemostasis, drainage. Critical control of the phrenic and recurrent nerves.
modes.normal: A surgery to remove a tumor in the chest between the lungs, where the main vessels and nerves pass. The surgeon shells the tumor like a nut, without damaging the surrounding tissue.

description.professional:
General endotracheal anesthesia with mechanical ventilation. Supine position with a cushion under the shoulder blades (for anterior mediastinum) or on the side (for posterior mediastinum). Monitoring of venous pressure through a catheter in the subclavian vein. Insertion of a urinary catheter. Thrombosis prevention (heparin 5000 U).
Instruments:
- Double-lumen endotracheal tube
- Central venous catheter
- Invasive blood pressure sensor
Technique:
1. For tumors >5 cm - arterial line in the radial artery.
2. Preparedness for emergency sternotomy in case of bleeding.
Logistics:
- Marking the tumor projection on the skin using CT.
Note: In case of myasthenia - avoid muscle relaxants.
description.normal:
The patient is placed on his back, placing a pillow under the thoracic region - this expands the space between the ribs. General anesthesia is administered and a special tube is inserted into the trachea for artificial respiration.
ðŸ“Œ Important: for tumors near the heart, an emergency blood transfusion device is always prepared.

description.professional:
Anterior mediastinum: partial sternotomy (upper for thymomas) or VATS (3 ports). Posterior mediastinum: thoracotomy along the 4th-5th intercostal space. Dissection of the mediastinal pleura along the phrenic nerve. Visualization of the tumor in the capsule.
Instruments:
- Oscillating sternum saw
- Thoracoscope 10 mm 30Â°
- Finochetto rib retractor
Technique:
1. For VATS - camera in the 5th intercostal space along the midaxillary line.
2. Protection of the internal thoracic artery during sternotomy.
Logistics:
- Intraoperative ultrasound to determine the boundaries.
Nuance: In case of invasive thymomas - readiness for thymectomy.
description.normal:
To access the tumor, the surgeon either partially dissects the sternum (as when opening a door) or makes 3-4 small incisions between the ribs for a video camera and instruments.
ðŸ“Œ Interesting: the phrenic nerve, which controls breathing, is highlighted with a bright blue ribbon - it cannot be damaged!

description.professional:
Blunt isolation of the capsule with a Penfield dissector. Gradual separation from the pericardium (with anterior mediastinum) or the spine (with posterior). Coagulation of feeding vessels with a 15 W bipolar. Identification and preservation of the brachiocephalic veins, superior vena cava, and recurrent laryngeal nerve.
Instruments:
- Harmonic scalpel
- DeBakey atraumatic clamps
- Metzenbaum scissors
Technique:
1. Starting the isolation from the least vascularized pole.
2. Using hydrodissection (saline + adrenaline).
Logistics:
- Marking the tumor orientation with 6-0 sutures.
Nuance: In case of cystic lesions - aspiration of the contents with an 18G needle.
description.normal:
The tumor is carefully Â«peeledÂ» from the surrounding tissues, as if peeling an orange, without damaging the capsule. Particular care is taken near large veins and nerves - they are wrapped in soft protective tapes.
ðŸ“Œ A tricky part: some tumors stick to the pericardium â€” then the surgeon uses an Â«electric scalpelÂ» that cuts and cauterizes at the same time.

description.professional:
Clipping of arterial branches from the internal mammary artery with titanium clips. Ligation of venous tributaries into the superior vena cava (Prolene 5-0 suture). Control of tumor bed hemostasis with a hemostatic sponge (Surgicel). Checking the integrity of the pleura.
Instruments:
- Clip applicator with medium clips
- Suture material with an atraumatic needle
- Floseal hemostatic matrix
Technique:
1. Suturing vessels Â«in two layersÂ» with a diameter of> 3 mm.
2. Use of argon-enhanced coagulation on the pericardium.
Logistics:
- Counting the number of installed clips.
Nuance: If the pleural cavity is damaged - install additional drainage.
description.normal:
The blood vessels feeding the tumor are clamped with tiny titanium clips and crossed. The area where the tumor was is treated with a special Â«hemostatic spongeÂ» - it dissolves in 2-3 weeks.
ðŸ“Œ Important: if the pleural cavity (lining of the lung) is opened, the surgeon immediately inserts an additional drainage tube.

description.professional:
Placing the preparation in an endobag. Expansion of one of the ports to 3-4 cm for extraction (for VATS). For large tumors - morcellation in a container. Urgent histological examination. Revision of the bed for the absence of residual tissue.
Instruments:
- EndoCatch endocontainer
- Morcellator with a protective cover
- Sterile measuring cup
Technique:
1. Avoid contact of the tumor with the wound edges.
2. Photographic recording of the stages for the protocol.
Logistics:
- Weighing the tumor indicating the volume.
Note: In case of teratomas, be careful with the contents (risk of infection).
description.normal:
The tumor is placed in a special container bag and removed through the largest puncture (or through an incision in the sternum). If the formation is too large, it is crushed inside the bag, like crushed ice for cocktails.
ðŸ“Œ Critical: the contents of cystic tumors should not get into the wound - this can cause inflammation!

description.professional:
Installation of drainage in the mediastinum (24 Fr) through a separate puncture. Layered suturing: sternum - with stainless steel wire, muscles - Vicryl 0, skin - intradermal suture. Connecting the drainage to the active aspiration system (-10 cm H2O).
Instruments:
- Pleurovac drainage
- Liston bone nippers
- Mathieu needle holder
Postoperative protocol:
1. X-ray/CT after 2 hours.
2. Pain relief: epidural anesthesia + Ketorolac.
3. Removing the drainage if the discharge is <100 ml/day.
Complications:
- Horner's syndrome (1%).
- Bleeding (2%).
- Chylothorox (rare).
description.normal:
A drainage tube is inserted into the mediastinum to remove blood and lymph. The sternum is secured with titanium staples, the muscles and skin are sutured with absorbable threads. After 4-6 hours, the patient is allowed to drink, and after 24 hours - to get up.
ðŸ“Œ Good news: most of these tumors are benign, and surgery provides a complete cure!

modes.professional: Radical removal of a tracheal tumor with circular or wedge resection, restoration of airway continuity. Stages: intubation of the tumor, access, mobilization of the trachea, resection with histological control of the edges, end-to-end anastomosis. Control of blood supply and anastomosis tension is critical.
modes.normal: Surgery to remove a tumor in the trachea (breathing tube) with subsequent suturing of healthy areas. Restores normal breathing and prevents suffocation.

description.professional:
Conscious induction (sedation + local anesthesia). Flexible bronchoscopy to assess patency. Intubation through the tumor with a narrow tube (6.0-6.5 mm) or above it. Alternative: high-frequency jet ventilation. Monitoring: SpO2, EtCO2, invasive BP.
Instruments:
- 4.2 mm video bronchoscope
- Parker Flex-Tip tubes
- HFJV device
Technique:
1. Â«SlidingÂ» intubation under visual control.
2. Backup tracheostomy for critical stenosis.
Logistics:
- Readiness for extracorporeal membrane oxygenation (ECMO).
Nuance: For subglottic tumors - intubation through a stoma.
description.normal:
The riskiest stage! A tube is inserted into the patient's trachea directly through the tumor - like a thread through a narrow eye of a needle. This is done very carefully so as not to block the remaining lumen.
ðŸ“Œ Emergency option: if the tumor almost completely blocks the trachea, they can immediately make an opening in the neck (tracheostomy).

description.professional:
Cross incision above the jugular notch + median sternotomy (for tumors of the lower third). Dissection of the band muscles of the neck. Isolation of the trachea from the cricoid cartilage to the bifurcation. Preservation of the lateral vascular bundles (risk: damage to the recurrent nerves).
Instruments:
- Colorado-tip electrocoagulator
- Tracheal retractors
- Nerve stimulator
Technique:
1. With cervical access - hyperextension of the neck on a bolster.
2. Mobilization of the trachea no more than 1 cm on each side.
Logistics:
- Marking the tumor with staples before resection.
Nuance: With carcinoids - avoid palpation of the tumor (risk of bronchospasm).
description.normal:
The surgeon makes an incision at the base of the neck and/or dissects the sternum. The trachea is freed from surrounding tissues, like a wire is cleaned of insulation.
ðŸ“Œ Caution: the nerves that control the voice pass nearby - damage to them will make the voice hoarse forever.

description.professional:
Circular resection (max. 5 cm in adults): transverse incisions above and below the tumor. Wedge resection for small lesions. Urgent histological examination of the edges. Lymph node dissection of the paratracheal nodes. Protection of the distal section with a sterile tube.
Instruments:
- Tracheal scissors with an angled blade
- Cryoapplicator for urgent biopsy
- Endotracheal tube for distal ventilation
Technique:
1. Resection with the capture of 1 cm of healthy tissue in cancer.
2. Preservation of the posterior membranous portion during wedge resection.
Logistics:
- The tumor is removed as a single block with tissue.
Nuance: In case of adenoid cystic cancer â€” frozen sections of all edges.
description.normal:
The surgeon cuts out a section of the trachea with the tumor, leaving clean edges â€” as when cutting off a damaged hose. The sections are sent for urgent analysis to make sure that the entire tumor has been removed.
ðŸ“Œ Life hack: if a large section needs to be removed, the trachea is â€œstretchedâ€ with special balloons before the operation â€” then the remaining ends are easier to connect.

description.professional:
Connection of the ends of the trachea with PDS 3-0 sutures: first the posterior membranous portion (continuous suture), then the anterior cartilaginous (separate interrupted sutures). Tension relief: submental suture to sternum, tongue root mobilization. Leak testing with saline under 30 cm H2O.
Instruments:
- Castroviejo needle holder
- Absorbable suture material
- Bronchoscope for control
Technique:
1. Sutures through cartilage without mucosal capture.
2. Knots outside to minimize granulomas.
Logistics:
- Use of a surgical microscope during reconstructions.
Nuance: In diabetes, add fibrin glue.
description.normal:
The ends of the trachea are sutured like the sleeves of a suit - first the back wall with a continuous suture, then the front wall with separate stitches. To prevent the sutures from coming apart, the patient's head is fixed in a bent position with a special collar.
ðŸ“Œ Important: each suture must be perfectly straight - the slightest fold will cause scarring and new stenosis.

description.professional:
Drainage of the anterior mediastinum (Blake 19Fr drainage). Layered suturing with muscle repositioning. Fixation of the chin to the sternum with a Â«straitjacketÂ» bandage (reduces tension). Extubation in the operating room with a stable anastomosis.
Instruments:
- Active drainage system
- Mental suture made of 2-0 nylon
- Rigid Philadelphia collar
Postoperative protocol:
1. Bronchoscopy on the 1st and 3rd days.
2. Parenteral nutrition for 5 days (immobilization of the neck).
3. CT after 1 month.
Complications:
- Anastomotic dehiscence (5%).
- Granulomas (8%).
- Restenosis (12% with radiation therapy).
description.normal:
After checking the tightness of the suture, drainage is placed and the wound is sutured. The patient is given a special collar that does not allow the neck to straighten for 2 weeks - the sutures should heal without tension.
ðŸ“Œ Amazing: most patients breathe on their own on the day of surgery â€” the trachea heals very quickly!

modes.professional: Surgical access to the chest cavity through the intercostal space or by resecting the rib. Main types: post-terolateral, axillary, anterior. It is used for operations on the lungs, heart, esophagus and mediastinum. Requires separate ventilation of the lungs and control of hemostasis of the intercostal vessels.
modes.normal: Surgery to open the chest to access the lungs, heart or other organs. The surgeon makes an incision between the ribs to reach the desired area.

description.professional:
Intubation with a double-lumen tube for separate lung ventilation. Position the patient on the healthy side with a cushion under the chest (for post-terolateral access). Preparation of the surgical field from the clavicle to the 12th rib. Placement of a urinary catheter and an arterial line.
Instruments:
- Double-lumen endotracheal tube
- Bronchoscope for positioning
- 20G arterial catheter
Technique:
1. Lung isolation test (collapse of the operated lung).
2. Preventive antibiotic therapy (cefazolin 2 g).
Logistics:
- Marking the blood pressure level on the dependent arm.
Nuance: In case of aortic pathology - a catheter in the right radial artery.
description.normal:
The patient is placed on his side, a special breathing tube is inserted, which allows one lung to be disconnected during surgery. This gives the surgeon space to work.
ðŸ“Œ Important: before the operation to check how the patient tolerates the disconnection of one lung - they do a test compression of the bronchus.

description.professional:
Skin incision along the V-VI intercostal space from the paravertebral line to the midclavicular. Layer-by-layer dissection: skin, subcutaneous tissue, latissimus dorsi muscle, serratus muscle. Electrocoagulation of bleeding vessels. Isolation of the intercostal space while preserving the vascular-nerve bundle.
Instruments:
- Scalpel No. 20
- Valleylab electrocoagulator
- Muscle hooks
Technique:
1. Incision along the upper edge of the underlying rib.
2. Blunt detachment of the periosteum with a raspatory.
Logistics:
- Used gauze swabs are counted.
Nuance: In repeated operations - access through the old scar field.
description.normal:
The surgeon makes an arcuate incision 15-20 cm long from the back to the armpit. He dissects the skin, subcutaneous fat and muscles layer by layer, exposing the ribs.
ðŸ“Œ Interesting: the incision is often made along the bra line in women - so that the seam is less noticeable.

description.professional:
Dissection of the intercostal muscles along the upper edge of the rib. Introduction of a retractor (Finochetto) with gradual spreading of the ribs by 10-15 cm. Revision of the pleural cavity for adhesions. In case of dense adhesions - careful blunt separation with a finger. Hemostasis of damaged vessels with clips.
Instruments:
- Rib retractor with ratchet
- Metzenbaum scissors
- Hemostatic clips
Technique:
1. Entry into the pleura in the posterior section (the layer is thinner there).
2. Control of the intercostal nerve.
Logistics:
- Change the retractor every 30 minutes to prevent neuropraxia.
Nuance: With osteoporosis - risk of rib fracture during retractor.
description.normal:
The surgeon carefully separates the muscles between the ribs, then inserts a special retractor, which gently pushes the ribs apart. It's like opening blinds - the view of the lung gradually opens up.
ðŸ“Œ Important: expand slowly to avoid breaking the ribs, especially in elderly patients.

steps.name: The main stage of the operation

description.professional:
Depending on the goal: lobectomy (ligation of lobar vessels and bronchus), pleurectomy (separation of the pleura from the chest wall), removal of a mediastinal tumor (isolation of the formation from vital structures). Control of hemostasis by bipolar coagulation. Drainage of the surgical field.
Instruments:
- Satinsky vascular clamps
- Ultrasonic dissector
- Pool aspirator
Technique:
1. During lobectomy - the sequence Â«artery-vein-bronchusÂ».
2. During pleurectomy - preservation of the endothoracic fascia.
Logistics:
- Labeling of preparations for histology.
Nuance: In case of cancer - mandatory mediastinal lymph node dissection.
description.normal:
Depending on the purpose of the operation, the surgeon can: remove part of the lung, remove a tumor, treat a purulent focus or perform other manipulations. Bleeding is monitored at all times and important structures are preserved.
ðŸ“Œ A difficult moment: when working near the heart or large vessels, every movement must be precise - like a sapper.

description.professional:
Installation of two drains (28-32 Fr): apical - for air, basal - for fluid. Layered suturing: intercostal muscles (Vicryl 2-0), latissimus dorsi (PDS 0), subcutaneous tissue (Vicryl 3-0), skin (stapler or subcuticular suture). Fixation of drains with stay sutures.
Instruments:
- Pleurovac chest drains
- Mathieu needle holder
- Skin stapler
Technique:
1. Drainage is performed through a separate puncture.
2. Sealing of sutures with a test with saline solution.
Logistics:
- Checking drains for fluctuations during breathing.
Nuance: In emphysematous patients - an additional pleural suture.
description.normal:
After completion of the main part, two plastic tubes are inserted into the chest - one removes air, the other liquid. The muscles and skin are sutured in layers.
ðŸ“Œ Important: drains are left for 2-3 days, they are removed when the lung has fully expanded and air stops leaking.

description.professional:
Transfer to the intensive care unit with SpO2, blood pressure, and diuresis monitoring. X-ray control 1 hour after surgery. Pain relief: epidural anesthesia + PCA pump. Activation after 4-6 hours with breathing exercises. Removal of drains in the absence of air/effusion (<100 ml/day).
Instruments:
- Analgosedation device
- Incentive spirometer
- Mobile X-ray machine
Postoperative protocol:
1. Antibiotics 24-48 hours.
2. Low molecular weight heparins 7 days.
3. Daily dressing.
Complications:
- Atelectasis (15-20%).
- Bleeding (3%).
- Persistent pain syndrome (8%).
description.normal:
After the operation, the patient is transferred to the intensive care unit, where breathing and drainage are monitored. After a few hours, help to sit up and start breathing deeply - this prevents complications.
ðŸ“Œ The main thing: despite the pain, you need to cough and breathe deeply - this way the lung will straighten out faster!

modes.professional: A surgical procedure for obliteration of the pleural cavity in case of recurrent effusions. Methods: mechanical (pleurectomy), chemical (talc, doxycycline) or combined. Stages: drainage of effusion, treatment of the pleura, drainage. Control of aerostasis and adequate pain relief are critical.
modes.normal: A procedure that Â«gluesÂ» the pleural layers together to prevent fluid accumulation in the lungs. Most commonly performed for cancer or persistent pneumothoraces.

description.professional:
General anesthesia with double-lumen intubation or local anesthesia for VATS. Position on the healthy side with arm abduction. Establishment of peripheral/central venous access. Premedication: fentanyl 1-2 mcg/kg, midazolam 1-2 mg. SpO2, ECG, BP monitoring.
Instruments:
- Thoracoscopic set
- Pleurovac drainage system
- Infusomat for anesthetics
Technique:
1. Lung isolation test during intubation.
2. Puncture of effusion under ultrasound navigation.
Logistics:
- Preparation of 2-3 liters of warm saline.
Nuance: For local anesthesia - add 1% lidocaine to the trocar insertion points.
description.normal:
The patient is placed on his side, general anesthesia or local anesthesia is administered. If a double-lumen tube is used, one lung is temporarily disconnected - this gives the surgeon space to work.
ðŸ“Œ Important: before the operation, be sure to remove the maximum amount of fluid through the puncture - this makes it easier to see the pleural cavity.

description.professional:
Thoracentesis along the midaxillary line in the 6-7 intercostal space (for VATS - 10 mm trocar). Aspiration of effusion with an electric suction pump. Inspection of the cavity: assessment of the degree of lung collapse, presence of adhesions, tumor nodes. Collection of fluid for cytology/biochemistry.
Instruments:
- 5-12 mm trocars
- Aspirator with adjustable pressure
- Containers for analysis
Technique:
1. Puncture of the Â«safe triangleÂ»: between the anterior serratus, latissimus dorsi muscles and the 5th rib.
2. Control of the absence of damage to the diaphragm.
Logistics:
- The volume of removed fluid is recorded (often 1-2 l).
Nuance: In case of hemorrhagic effusion - lavage until Â«clear watersÂ».
description.normal:
A tube is inserted through a small incision or puncture and all accumulated fluid is removed. The surgeon examines the cavity through a camera - looking for tumor nodes or areas of inflammation.
ðŸ“Œ Interesting: sometimes cancer cells are found in the fluid - this helps to clarify the diagnosis.

description.professional:
Chemical pleurodesis: spraying 4-5 g of sterile talc (or doxycycline 500 mg in 100 ml of saline). Mechanical: pleural abrasion with a hard brush/gauze. Combined: talc after pleurectomy. Control of complete lung straightening under a pressure of 20 cm H2O.
Instruments:
- Talc applicator (spray system)
- DeVilbiss thoracoscopic brush
- Electrocoagulator for hemostasis
Technique:
1. In VATS - treatment of all sections (apical, diaphragmatic).
2. Uniform distribution of the sclerosant.
Logistics:
- Talc exposure time is 10 min.
Nuance: In case of mesothelioma - additional photodynamic therapy.
description.normal:
The most important stage! Sterile talc (like baby powder) is sprayed into the cavity - it causes inflammation and Â«stickingÂ» of the pleural sheets. An alternative is special chemical solutions or even mechanical Â«sandingÂ» of the pleura.
ðŸ“Œ Important: the lung must be completely straightened before applying talc - otherwise there will be no effect.

description.professional:
Installation of two 28-32 Fr drains: apical (for air) and basal (for liquid). Connection to the active aspiration system (-20 cm H2O). Checking the tightness with a suture around the drains. Layer-by-layer suturing of wounds. Fixing the drains with sutures/adhesive tape.
Instruments:
- Pigtail drain
- Prolene 2-0 suture material
- Oasis vacuum system
Technique:
1. Drainage is carried out through a separate puncture.
2. Control of air bubbles.
Logistics:
- Daily recording of the volume of discharge.
Nuance: In case of ongoing pneumothorax - Heimlich system.
description.normal:
Two tubes are inserted into the chest: one removes air, the other - the remaining fluid. They are connected to a vacuum system - like a vacuum cleaner. The puncture sites are carefully sutured.
ðŸ“Œ Note: drains can be left in place for several days until the lung has fully straightened.

description.professional:
X-ray immediately after surgery. Pain relief: NSAIDs + opioids (tramadol 50 mg every 6 hours). Drains are removed when the daily volume is <100 ml and there is no air. Antibiotic therapy (ceftriaxone 1 g / day for 3 days). Control CT after 7 days.
Instruments:
- Portable X-ray machine
- Infusomat for analgesia
- Pleural biopsy system
Postoperative protocol:
1. Breathing exercises from the 1st day.
2. Activation after 4-6 hours.
3. Ultrasound if relapse is suspected.
Complications:
- Empyema (2-3%).
- ARDS (with talc) <1%.
- Recurrence of effusion (5-10%).
description.normal:
Immediately after the operation, they take an X-ray to check how the lung has straightened out. The drains are removed when air and fluid stop coming out (usually after 2-3 days).
ðŸ“Œ Good news: in 90% of patients after pleurodesis, effusion no longer accumulates for months!

modes.professional: Surgical removal of the gallbladder by laparoscopic or open method. Main stages: access, isolation of the cystic duct and artery, mobilization of the gallbladder, hemostasis. Critical point - identification of the triangle of Calot.
modes.normal: Surgery to remove the gallbladder, most often due to stones. It is done through small punctures (4 holes) - the patient recovers in 2-3 days.

description.professional:
General endotracheal anesthesia with muscle relaxation. Supine position with the head end down (anti-Trendelenburg) and left rotation. Insertion of a nasogastric tube with an overfilled stomach. Treatment of the surgical field from the xiphoid process to the pubis.
Instruments:
- Macintosh laryngoscope No. 3
- Endotracheal tube 7.0-7.5 mm
- Chlorhexidine-based antiseptic
Technique:
1. Preoxygenation with 100% oxygen for 3 minutes
2. Induction with propofol (2 mg/kg) + fentanyl (1-2 mcg/kg)
Logistics:
- Airway pressure control <12 mm Hg.
Nuance: In case of obesity (BMI>35) - intubation with a video laryngoscope.
description.normal:
The patient is placed on his back, slightly tilting the table so that the legs are above the head. General anesthesia is administered - the person falls asleep and does not feel anything. The abdomen is treated with an antiseptic - from the sternum to the pubis.
ðŸ“Œ Important: before the operation, be sure to check for allergies to anesthesia drugs!

description.professional:
Veresh needle puncture at Calca point (1 cm above the navel). CO2 insufflation to a pressure of 12-14 mm Hg. Control of uniform gas distribution. Insertion of the first 10 mm trocar under visual control. Installation of a 30Â° laparoscope.
Instruments:
- 150 mm Veresh needle
- Insufflator with gas heating
- Trocar with a safety valve
Technique:
1. Â«Suspended dropÂ» test to confirm the intraperitoneal position
2. Gradually increase the pressure from 8 to 14 mm Hg.
Logistics:
- CO2 consumption no more than 30-40 l per operation
Nuance: In case of adhesions - open access Hasson.
description.normal:
Carbon dioxide is pumped into the stomach through a puncture in the navel - the stomach inflates like a balloon. This is necessary so that the surgeon can see and work. Then a camera is inserted - now everything is visible on the screen.
ðŸ“Œ Interesting: the gas is not harmful and is completely eliminated after the operation!

description.professional:
Installation of working ports under visual control: epigastric (10 mm), right subcostal (5 mm), additional in the left subcostal region if necessary. The Â«American trapezoidÂ» position - the surgeon is on the left, the assistant is on the right of the patient.
Instruments:
- Trocars with fixing cuffs
- Videolaparoscopic stand
- Maryland instruments and atraumatic clamps
Technique:
1. Epigastric port - 3 cm below the xiphoid process
2. Right subcostal - along the midclavicular line
Logistics:
- Fixation of trocars to the skin with sutures
Nuance: During pregnancy - displacement of ports upward.
description.normal:
They also do 2-3 punctures (each 5-10 mm) in different places of the abdomen. Instruments are inserted through them: one Â«holdsÂ» the liver, the other works. The surgeon sits and looks at the screen, where everything is magnified 10 times!
